content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								I bought into this game quite some time ago, when it was still in early development.My decision was based on the idea of an update to the God-Game genre, I still fondly recall experimenting with the original Black & White when I was much younger - and I also quite enjoyed the sequel.At first glance I thought to myself "uhhh, this looks like it might suck"(but, given that it was so early and there was practically no game there, thought I'd come back later)I keep checking in every few months, and even now (2014 is about to turn into 2015 thisevening), all I really have is a sense of vague disappointment and worry that the whole exercise is a waste of time.  I hope each time I check for some evolutionary change (heh, evolution in a God game)...... but each time I check, it just looks and feels .. lame.Sorry, a good piece of feedback should somehow quantify - and it's hard to sum it up.  Graphically and game-play wise, it just seems like a heavily scripted made-for-mobile experience.A God Game should give you a pale shadow of an impression of how it would feel to be an ultimate being.  People worship you, you protect/punish them, you stun them with the miraculous, you ... etc etcThis game, you just feel like some kind of disembodied structural world janitor.Sorry, every time I've booted up I've found it boring - and the card and progression concept to be actively painful.

number of helpful: 11 of 11 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								After giving this game almost an entire year of time to change my mind, I'm finally writing a review.Around last Christmas time I found this game, and I looked into it, and read about what it was supposed to be like. Considering that I'm a huge fan of Minecraft, this seemed like a really wonderful game that would offer similar mechanics and a beautiful art style. It also boasted that it wasn't yet complete, and that tons of other features would be added.Throughout my time playing Godus, i quickly realized that it wasn't what was promised. There are many, many things that are disappointing, frustrating, and down right infuriating. The worst part is that when I redownloaded it recently, I expected that some of these basic things would be improved upon. They haven't been. Based on that, I'm writing this review.The worst and most disappointing thing is that this game truly became a mobile 'waiting' game. It works with the same mechanics as Farmville, but the in-game mechanics and balancing of certain features are worse. When I purchased the game initially I thought that it wouldn't be like this at all. It really cheapens the idea of what could have been an amazing game.My biggest beef is that within the year that I didn't play it, I came back to the game being more buggy, having worse balance issues, and being more laggy on my system for no reason. I kept having the repeated issue of cards not appearing when I completed an objective, or the finger of god not working properly. The spacing of buildings has obviously been changed from what I remember, it is no longer as intuitive and everything is poorly spaced. Every UI aspect has gotten more and more annoying, like if I have a new card, the pulsating of the top right button is aggrivating. The way that the stickers have been rebalanced seems way, way worse. There is now one, maybe two stickers in every treasure box, whereas a year ago it was more randomized and you could find between 1-5 stickers in a box. They are almost forcing you to used the voyage function, however that hasn't been upgraded or improved since last year either. They've made it increasingly challenging to get stickers and gems in the worst way, because it now feels like sculpting to find treasure boxes isn't worth the belief, and the voyages only yield a small amount of a specific sticker at every goal reached. Honestly that alone was so annoying that I just stopped improving any card that I didn't think was necessary- and in doing that it appeared that new cards weren't appearing anymore when I completed a goal.My final, most infuriating issue with this game is the Astari aspect. Nothing is explained well enough, their appearance in the game isn't explained enough, and the way that their mechanic works makes no sense. You basically have to rely on the finger of god power, and once you've done that, there is absolutely no point in creating or pushing for the military settlements. Since the Astari and the reason that they are in the game is never explained, they feel like a giant annoyance that continually pesters you. The fact that the only real option is to wipe them out by saving up belief and then either squishing them during their festival or squishing a tree and then squishing them in rounds of 4-5 feels both annoying and cheap. They also somehow gain happiness at an inhumane level, which makes it incredibly challenging to not eradicate them immediately so that you just don't have to deal with them any more. Apparently the one thing that has been entirely reworked is the fighting mechanics, which I didn't even have a chance to see. Between cards that I remember being there a year ago being removed, the gem system being ridiculously unbalanced (considering that now basically your only option to progess in cards is to gain gems to buy packs, instead of it being about the finding of treasure or even the voyages), and how the sculpting is still the most tedious and uninuitive feature in the game... I'm uninstalling, I'm never reinstalling. I'm thankful that I bought this game on sale for $5, but even that doesn't feel worth the money at this point.My advice to the developers? Drop the project. You released this game 2 years ago and have made no improvements for at least a year. Try not to screw up this hard next time.

								i was excited when i saw godus on steam, i bought it even though it was still in early access; the video i'd seen and the name attached to the game were large factors in that.on first play i noticed right away that the feel of the game was for mobile and not for the pc. figured i could live with that, wth. well, turns out there were all sorts of obvious mechanics that were meant for micro-transactions, all to be implemented later on, which made the gameplay ridiculous on a pc. game turned frustrating pretty quick. i uninstalled it and let it sit for about a year before i returned hoping development had come further and my gripes had been solved.i returned to find total silence from 22cans, a community stewing in anger, development seemingly come to a standstill, developers in the wind, and a game that was still frustrating. promises had been made! suggestions would be considered! all pretty much empty words.then a ray of hope, new builds, and the silence from the devs is broken. except, the same thing happens again. at this point i'm just fed up. i know the game is in EA but the writing's pretty clearly on the wall. maybe i'll return again if it ever goes gold, but until then, it's a big disappointment. too bad to, i really enjoyed Dungeon Keeper and Fable.

content:

Early Access Review
								Don't bother with this pile of garbage. Peter Molyneux is a known overhyper and swindler. I paid $20 for this a year and a half ago and its the same pile of unfun micro management garbage that offers absolutely nothing new to the god game genre. And its just kills me to look at the same terrible ui and visuals that have plagued this game since its inception. The developers have abandoned ship and Molyneux is too busy with the mobile version. I could have invested that $20 in far better indie games. MULTIPLE far better indie games.Who at 22Cans studios thought that the NEXT EVOLUTION of God games would be:*Continuously deform terrain for hours so that there is FLAT space where you can build houses.*Click your current houses so that your followers will go out and build houses on flat spaces, increasing population.*Continue to deform terrain so you can discover 'cards' that let you research new things.*Rinse, repeat, until you've unlocked all research, and rinse, repeat until your 'Civilization' looks a Rio De Janeiro ghetto that spans the entire world, is filled with huts on one side where you started, and manor houses on the other where your technology has advanced. Then realize the entire time you've been playing a glorified mobile time waster game where you wait for your houses to reach a certain time, then click on them to collect 'god power'. Then, wait until they're ready to be HARVESTED again, and click it again! OH BOY, SO MUCH FUN. I'M DYING FROM THE FUN. IT'S LIKE A PC VERSION OF FARMVILLE.HONESTLY, Black & White 2 was far more fun than this pile of garbage. Why didn't Molyneux decide to make a Black & White 3, and fulfil all the hyped up promises and features that he NEVER put in Black & White 2?Why Peter Molyneux or anyone at 22Cans could possibly think from the beginning that this monotonous, personality-less gameplay they developed could EVER turn into anything marginally fun to play is BEYOND me.Terrible from inception, and with the way the games structured now, theres no way it could ever be fun.I want my $20 back, but I know that'll never happen. And lets be clear here, I didn't buy this a month ago and now I'm freaking over the fact that the game hasn't changed entirely in a month. I BOUGHT IT ONE AND A HALF YEARS AGO.2/10Fun for the first 20 minutes.

								Just to start this off: This game is crap.When I bought the game about a year and a half ago, I was expecting a game type where I sculpted a world and played in a sandbox. What I got was nothing close to that. What I got was a game with no menu and no way to quit where I started on a sand island with a hut on it. I had to pop these stupid pink bubbles and get these points to use my powers. The bubbles gave me about 0.01 points each, and I could use about 5 seconds of my powers even when I stocked up on the bubbles for 3 days.There was no exploration aspect of the game. You would always run out of trees and rocks to get extra points. You got about 2 yards of extra space every time you used all of your resources to expand more. The continuous crashes. The not at all needed mesas, which you had to use all your powers to climb over, and there was nothing at the top except for a new area and then ANOTHER F*CKING MESA.Do not waste your money on this game. number of helpful: 10 of 10 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								Don't buy this.As I write, the game now hasn't been updated in nearly 2 years. The developer hasn't spoken to the community for nearly a full year. There is no-one working on this title. It is incomplete and dead, and it was pretty much dead before that too - there was a total of maybe 3 updates for the game, ever, and 22 Cans don't talk about it. The official forum mysteriously disappeared. They churned through community managers, and then basically stopped hiring them. Godus is, at it's heart, a mobile game. The intention is to make it pay-to-win, with you paying to speed up the time between rewards in exactly the manner Peter Molyneux slammed DK mobile for. This PC version exists purely so that Molyneux could make PC gamers pay for the development of the mobile money-spinner via kickstarter. In it's current state, it could more or less be drummed up in a game jam over a weekend in Unity... only you'd probably do a better job of making it fun.It's actually offensive that Steam haven't intervened and removed this game from the store, since it's not 'early access' - it's never going to go anywhere from here, and it is basically an elaborate kickstarter fraud.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game itself has a lot of potential.  You're a god, you get to shape and morph the land around you and help an entire population grow and prosper.  However, as it currently stands, there are so many improvements needed, that one might quit playing after an hour of repetitive clicking and expanding, clicking and expanding, clicking, and, you guesed it, trying to expand.The card resource system is flawed.  Once you can't find cards, you're out of luck for trying to upgrade any of your next improvements.  The game is currently only 40% unlocked, so I hope this issue is resolved with expansion and more multiplayer battles for cards. Either, or as someone else mentioned, a system in which resources can be mined or harvested.My finger goes numb from all the clicking.  Every house your citizens build accumulates more influence, the main source of your power in the game.  After a while, if you want to collect influence, you have to go back and individually click every house that has available influence to give to you.  I really wish there was some sort of "collect all" option, but sadly, there is not.Overall, This game has some serious flaws that ruin the enjoyability of the game pretty quickly.  I don't know why I put as many hours into it as I did.  Hopefully, the game improves, but until then, I would not recommend this game to anyone.

number of helpful: 13 of 16 people (81%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
Early Access Review
OMG, no!For pity's sake, don't plow any more funding into this half-baked project. Would you pay money for the first few chapters of a mystery novel, when the author is saying "Don't worry, once I have your money I'm sure I'll have some really great ideas about how to write the rest of it. Of course, I'll be spending most of my time working on the first few chapters of my next novel..."Godus in its current state offers a few hours of really good gameplay. Then it stops. There's some nice graphics, excellent music, interesting mechanics. But no actual game. You can play the starting phase over and over, but you hit the same wall every time.At least the concept is good. I was more enthusiastic about Godus than I am about the endless me-too projects we're seeing in Early Access lately. But with Peter Molyneux actually admitting that he's scaling back development on Godus - and, unbelievably, putting a fan with no development experience in charge! - I'm losing hope. Maybe this new guy will make it work, but I see no reason anyone should put another nickel into this thing until there's a major sign it's actually going somewhere.Early Access is a really cool idea, but it's in dire need of some tough love. Stop funding projects too soon. Never fund projects until they really show that they have a strong plan for a complete game - not just a beginning and some vague mumbles about how great it's going to be - someday.

number of helpful: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								All the Bullfrog games, Lionhead studios and others with titles such as Populous, Dungeon Keeper, Fable, Black & White... I loved P. Molyneux' games or ones that he was involved with. I was even able to see past the bad of Black & White 2. With all these games in mind I was so eager to kickstart this game, well.. biggest consumer mistake ever.It's now a decade or two later that I realise it's not Peter M. who was this brilliant game designer, it was always the combined efforts of his ideas backed by a developer team which wasn't afraid to say "No Peter, that's a bad idea, we can't do that". I think that this time around he was surrounded by young devs who dare not speak up enough against such a "legend" and that's where Godus went wrong.I'd give you a helpful list of what's wrong and what's not however there is no need, check it out on mobile for free, the same paywall mechanics are present in the PC version and weren't somewhat "changed" until a huge outrage (one of several) from the community. Every other feature is the exact same on the PC version. Multiplayer will never see the light of day so there's a con for ya. It's not in a fancy summarised list, sorry, I'd do that if there was still hope for this game in the future, but there is not, not an ounce.It breaks my heart to say this, I had such high hopes for the game, but please don't buy it, it's broken and unfinished, don't give him a cent, don't spend a cent on his new game "The trail". This mans golden years are over, he is no longer backed by strong willed and seasoned developers like he used to be in the past, he is the M Night Shyamalan of the gaming industry.

number of helpful: 16 of 22 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
Early Access Review
								In its current state, Godus is a chore more than a game. You click, click, click until your hand gets numb, with little to reward you other than more things to click on.  Everything feels like it is designed not to entertain you, but to keep you busy. There is progression, but only in a sense that things start off tedious, and then you are given tools to make your gameplay slightly less tedious. You start off having to click on each individual house to gather belief, with which you can sculpt land. If there was some moderation to this it would be alright, but it literally takes hours to get anywhere and your wrist will start hurting from the hundreds of times per minute you have to click to get a decent patch of land for your villagers to settle on. Then you are given some new tools through which you can do more while clicking less, which does make the game less tedious, but with a focus on the word less - and there still isn't anything that actually entertains. It would help if your villagers seemed to have lives of their own, but even on that front not much seems to happen. They just stay in their houses until you decide they are allowed to come out - then, when there is no place for them to settle, they just die.I would advice people who are on the fence about this game to first watch some movie reviews before purchasing this game, as there are quite a number of decent reviews out there that pinpoint exactly where this train went off the rails.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Update, Feb 2017.This game hasn't been updated for two years, so consider this the post mortem.In the end, Godus turned out to be a pay-to-progress Farmville style ipad game, with a nifty sculpting mechanic, which was later nerfed because players spent too much time sculpting and not enough spending money.The PC game originally promised, was essentially just a lie, told to leverage more money from the PC community, for development which was never spent on developing a PC game.Peter Molyneux was eventually called out for his lies by several gaming sites and has since retreated out of the spotlight, vowing never to show his face again. Many felt that, since 22Cans comitted fraud, on a fairly large scale, no future products from 22Cans should ever be allowed on Steam.The final part of the mystery remains that Godus/Godus Wars are still available on Early Access, despite the projects having been abandonned a long time ago.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Huge dissapointment. Not even close to the good ole god games everyone has come to know and love, and I am not sure if it ever will even get to that point. From watching the dev videos, reading blogs. This game is aimed more towards casual play, lacking the content, and depth a god game deserves.At this point the game is nothing more than sculpting land, and clicking thousands of times on houses to get followers out or to collect the little orbs (faith?) so you can use your powers (which are pointless). Everything in the game right now is pointless. The followers do nothing on their own, have no AI. Man I could go on ranting forever. The updates to this game are extremely slow, and we were promised updates at a lot faster pace. Also the devs don't really come around to often or fill us in with anything worthwhile. The game is surviving on Peters name, and that is it. This is not worthy of a single penny much less the $19 they are asking for now, or whatever the cost is now. Let me make it short and sweet.- If you like doing mundane tasks, for no reward at all. Then pick up this game.- If you do not have high expectations and do not care if you are let down, and have money to waste. Pick up this game.- If you feel you have been neglecting your mouses buttons lately, and feel it needs a work out. Get this game.- If you are trying to wear out your mouse, so you can convince your parents, wife, girlfriend, etc. To get a new one. Get this game.- If you are expecting a game like Populous. Avoid this game like the plague. The only thing similar is the followers and that is even pushing it.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
Early Access Review
EDIT 28 March 2014: The developer is now more communicative with their players and has released a major update to the game. The game is overall much less of a chore to play now but it's still based on social game conventions, in other words, most of the gameplay consist of waiting for real world hours to recharge belief, build shrines or refilling a boat embark on voyages (missions that play like a simplified version of Lemmings). The gameplay additions are welcome, but unfortunately the number of bugs and crashes of the game has increased. I would recommend to wait a little more until the game is more complete and polished before spending 18,99€ on it.-----------OLD REVIEW:I know that when you buy an Early Access / in-development game you can't expect it to contain most of the promised features at first, but at least I expect regular communication from the developers (weekly or even monthly updates about its development). There hasn't been any announcement on the Steam Community since October, and their Facebook and Twitter feeds appear more interested in selling t-shirts than talking about the game.  I'm not asking for a big content update patch every week, but at least they should inform us about what they are working on (and I'm referring to what is being worked on for the 1.4 patch for example, not just cryptic "we are working hard on your feedback and have big ideas for the future" kind of videos that just make more far-off promises). I feel like they have no pressure whatsoever in finishing the game, as they have my money already.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								Back in the distant Eighties, Peter Molyneux created the first 'god game' POPULOUS. An early milestone in personal gaming. Simple but instructive UI, a logical and addictive mechanic, challenging progression and a true sense of achievement when a game was won. Nowadays, we are presented with monetisation: in-game purchases, carrot & stick condescension; a dumbed-down, craven ideology - tantalising to look at but utterly devoid of fun - the essential ingredient of a 'good game'. I want a story about humanity's impact on the world, a wise fable about the consequences of unfettered exploitation, the threat of climate change - prehistoric as well as contemporary. An archaeological story rich with detail, humour and frivolity. What happened to you Peter???

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								This text may be a little bit longer, so here is my conclusion up front: See this as a warning:This is not a game, it‘s also not a „Zen-Like“ experience. It‘s another Mobile/F2P cash-grab waiting to happen. I haven‘t seen anything this brash since the Dungeon Keeper Mobile „game“.  As a Kickstarter-Backer I feel betrayed by Molyneux and 22Cans and the only reason I checked the latest update (2.1) was out of morbid curiosity.It just sucks, don‘t buy it! If you are really curious, just wait for professional reviews to tear this thing apart. Or look at all the other negative reviews here. Many of the more realistic people have abandoned this F2P garbage long ago, just search the forums for a bit, or check the Kickstarter comments: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/22cans/project-godus/commentsHowever: Most reviews are still negative, and with good reason:Maybe I should start with the only positive thing I have to say about Godus: There are so many timers that I can go off and do pretty much anything else, until they finally run out. I‘m not kidding: I played through the Expendrabros campaign and I still had to wait another 10 minutes until anything happened in this „game“.Even simple buildings take up to 30 minutes to build, depending on their size. Well, you could say: Isn‘t there an upgrade that accelerates building time by 90%?Yes, there is, but now you need wheat to build new houses. First of all you need a farming settlement to get farmers, which costs 3000 belief, which, at this point of the game, takes more than one hour to gather.Now there are another 30 minutes until you can send out the first farmer, who needs 90 to 120 minutes to give you 2 – 4 wheat, depending on the size of the field.The next building you unlock after gaining the ability to create farms takes 30 minutes again and needs 6 wheat, so yay, even more timers.Later on you get mining settlements, which cost 7500 belief, which is not so bad at this point. Just gather the belief you can get right now, shut Godus down, play Sins of a Solar Empire Rebellion for a hour or two, check into Godus again, gather belief, and so on. It should only take about 5 hours. Miners now take one hour to spawn und the mines take 6 hours to give you anything.Oh, and you only get belief after a timer runs out, small buildings take about 20 minutes, settlements about 5 hours.(and that‘s also the reason some people have so many hours of Godus on their steam account: it‘s something you just have running in the background. It‘s NOT actual gameplay)But there is a solution for this problem: Gems!You can use gems to finish any timer. You can „earn“ some gems by voyages (about 29 in total, which is a joke) or you sacrifice some of your followers. That wouldn‘t be so bad, because the little guys and gals don‘t have any personality whatsoever, if the game wouldn‘t try to make you feel bad about it (which doesn‘t bother me either). And then the „game“ suddenly starts to punish you badly for unhappy followers without warning. Everything else get‘s a unskippable tutorial, except the happiness „system“, so it come‘s really unexpected in an otherwise astonishing linear „game“. You see: Followers become unhappy, if you send them to their doom, what you will want to do, so you don‘t have to wait for hours until you are able to do anything again. It doesn‘t have any impact on their behaviour, so nothing is lost here, but there is one problem: There is another tribe, the Astari, who don‘t really do anything, no expanding, nothing (there is no AI to speak of, so far, and I don‘t think there will ever be any). They aren‘t even on the same island as you and all they do at the beginning is mock your people, so they want build so fast. Not really a threat.But: When your people are not as happy as the Astari, they leave you periodically, and you can do nothing to stop them. A lot of people will leave you (the first time this happened to me, I lost 125 of about 400 people). So not only do you have to start the whole process of waiting all over again, you also have to get your people happy.Either you use some simple miracles and spend a lot of believe (thousends of it), which will take you forever, or you spend some gems on fountains and special trees. It‘s kinda like Fable III: They have no personality, they just react to stuff, which has some consequences and otherwise they only have some idle animations (I checked Fable III out after becoming disappointed about Godus, and I would have never ever backed it, if I had known what a trainwreck Fable turned out to be). They do nothing else: They don‘t build on their own, no exploration. It‘s all micro-managing.Basicly: Every aspect of this game screams cashshop, like in the free Mobile version. If you ever read Molyneuxs reaction to Dungeon Keeper Mobile, than you might find it funny that you can spend 70$ for gems in the shop.Right now you can‘t guy any gems for real money in the „PC version“ and 22Cans keep reassuring us, that this won‘t ever be possible on PC, but frankly, after almost two years of misdirection (just check the Kickstarter page), broken promises (weekly updates) and just straight up lies (for example the FAQ of the Kickstarter page), I see no reasons to trust those people anymore.In my opinion they are designing the whole game to be absolutly tedious without the use of gems, just so they can get in the cashshop with the argument, that we asked for it.The controls are awful with mouse and keyboard, the sculpting is imprecise and the graphics are just horrible, especially the animations, when zoomed out just a little bit. They even got worse since the Mobile launch. There isn‘t even a free rotating camera. They have been focusing on Mobile for the last two years, and it shows.While checking through some other Steam reviews I saw one that said „This game comes along nicely“, and I have to disagree! Godus has been in development for almost two years now (December 2012) and for almost one in Early Access (September 2013). In one year, they added the happiness system, and almost nothing else. There have been minor things, like having to grind wheat and ore in addition to the believe, but mostly it‘s only a variation of the stuff there already is. Oh, and there were the voyages, the only thing reminding me of a real game, simply because it‘s a cheap Lemmings knockoff. The „game“ has even lost more features than it gained. There are no multiplayer skirmishes anymore, and there is no „campaign“. While both were awfull, they at least had potential. Apart from that, there really isn‘t much to say about the game itself, because there really isn‘t much. It is awfully linear. You grind three kinds of things (people, farms and mines) to get new abilities and bonuses. It‘s just another Mobile/F2P game.In comparison: The majority of the Steam community and the Kickstarter backers told 22Cans that they don‘t want any timers and especially no gems, and just look how that turned out. Molyneux is really great at nullifying the critics: The Steam community doesn‘t matter, because it doesn‘t understand the concept of Early access. The Kickstarter Backers don‘t matter, because basicly he just wanted to get the reinvention of the god game financed, but Kickstarter forced him to write all those promises and stuff. I am really, really sick of it. yourself: 


YouTube™ Video: Peter Molyneux on Gaming's Future, Kickstarter Games and New Godus Gameplay! 

			Views: 26,998		

			Peter Molyneux sat down with Tara to show off the latest build of his first Kickstarter game, Godus, and all the new features we can expect to see in upcoming weeks.		

I really have no hope for this game, whatsoever. Just stay away from it, or wait for some final verdicts by game journalists, if you really have to. Personally, I will never buy anything for 22Cans again and I am looking forward for the inevitable failure of Godus and hopefully of the studio behind it.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Still an incredibly slow game.  It feels like "Farm Ville" or "The simpsons" Ipad app's.  Clicking to earn belief on every single house so you can use your godly powers is a pain and becomes tedious.  Having buildings that take 5 - 15 min to build is boring.  Searching for treasure underground to unlock resourses and flattening ground... thats all I feel like I'm doing.  You can play some side mini games that are dull and unchallenging.  You get stuck to a tiny little bit of land that you have to work on expanding that takes a lot of time and energy.  You can order your people around to build things, I like that but I hope you dont mind using all your belief ordering a few villagers around.  The cards you earn don't seem like a great achievement/ and or very exciting to unlock.Summary:If you don't mind a slow iphone game that takes ages to build anything and you have to tap the screen to gather your resources then this is a game for you.  If you don't mind expanding a city full of people that do absolutly nothing unless you tell them to then this is a game for you.  The game has a dull dead feeling to it, you build a city for what?  the people don't move around, they dont gather resources to build new places and have to be told what to do.Would not recomment

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								it is very hard to rate this piece of software and stay polite. I have been simply trolled by Peter Molyneux, who promised a lot during kickstarter campaign, regenesis of genre, jupiter sized world etc... Developers declared they are inspired by games like Populous, Black and White, Dungeon Keeper, Civilisation or Minecraft. Sounds great. But after 2 years of development they delivered us facebook-like clicking "game" (not a PC game) with an aggressive money-grabbing system. There is no strategy in the game. The core of game is based on enormous long timers and collecting of stickers. Unfortunately it is hard to see how Godus lost its potential, because on the other hand there exist a great community around Godus with many experienced players who suggested really cool solutions to developers how to make Godus enjoyable, but they do not listen to feedback.Godus is delicious as hell.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								During the kickstarter, Peter was quite dishonest with us. He didn't mention that he wants to make a mobile game about waiting. I honestly hoped this will be the next populus or black and white, but sadly I've got FarmVille like game where you wait for basically everything. It's not that I'm impatient but this is just tedious and frustrating to wait and grind dull voyages. There are still a lot I like about this game, and it would be very promissing, but there's no way they will make a propper game out of this, instead of stupid clicking cow, even though there's almost no clicking now. Waiting simulator in tags, suits this game pretty well. Sitting for hours in waithing for something to finish is no fun at all. Regret backing it back in the day, but shame on me. Truly the god game, that makes you feel really powerless.To be fair, I actually like the new village system. It looks cool, and it feels cool, except that obnoxious waiting times. It was the only thing that kept me going.But after you unlock  happines thing, you suddenly discover that your people will leave if they are unhappy. And Peter was saying "GO AHEAD THROW SOME OF THAT FOLLOWERS IN THE PIT OF DOOOOM!", and not actually telling that theres a consicuence for doing so. Great damn idea, they leave in like packs of 50 people and it takes bloody 24 hours to replenish them. TWENTY FOUR FREAKING HOURS OF WAITING BEFORE YOU WILL LOOSE 50 MORE!  Before that I was thinking "Ok I can still play once in an hour for 5 minutes, whatever, theres no way around it", but now I give up, this is just poor iOS game design. Should have told your damn backers that you are making an iOS game, this is no Regenesis of nothing.Honestly, I don't give a damn about cross play. Do a separate game for phones if you really want that kind of crap, but let the PC gamers have an actuall game... you know... the one you can PLAY. For now I can't recomend this disappointing thing to any sane person. As a matter of fact, they need to make something godly miraculous (haha a pun =_=) for this to be recomendable to anybody ever.P.S. Peter said that we shouldn't freak out about gems, but why shouldn't we, Peter? Yeah, we don't need to pay for 'em but clearly they are in the game only because of smartphones. And the ways to acuire them don't make any difference, since everything is too slow anyway.I might sound really hursh, but am I? Investing your money, and most importantly your HOPES in people, who clearly don't have your interests in mind, convinsing people that this time Peter will do it right, and actually beliving in that while all the hate♥♥♥♥♥♥was thrown around. Well, congrats people, you were right, you may laugh now, it can't get more sour that that anyway.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								I followed the Kickstarter progress with great anticipation.  When the first version came out, I played it for a while.  It was very rough around the edges, but it had potential.  Now it's 3 or more major iterations later, and things have actually gotten worse.  Your people are either very stupid, or try to kill themselves on purpose.  The land sculpting was fun in the beginning, but has gotten so epensive now, it's not worth the trouble.  And then there is the waiting...  If you like free to play crap where you have to wait 30 minutes for a house to be built (or give us some gems and you get it instantly) then you will LOVE this game.  But it has no place in a PC environment.  PC games tends to sit down for an hour or more gaming session, not a 5 minute "click on everything and queue it all up so you can wait again tomorrow."  And even though the PC version of Godus has no method to buy gems for cash, it still is the same mentality.I am very disappointed.  The only bright side I can see is that the game is currently 50.5% complete.  Hopefully they can still bring this game back.

								The only way I can see this game moving forward is to scrap it and start again.If you think that "the regenesis of the god game", the genre that contains industry defining games, made by the person who started it all (you know, the one who oversells his ideas), should be a mobile game, then buy this on iOS. You've stated many times how there will be no microtransactions in the Pc version. Could you at least redesign the second currency so that it is not obnoxious? All you've done is remove the payment part. The only way to get more Gems is to screw yourself over.This isn't the regenesis of the god game, this is the death of it. If you're thinking of buying this, please don't.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								So Peter Molyneux is at it again. And by "it" I mean making really, really bad games, while promising you the moon.After setting up his kickstarter to get morons like me to fund the game, it quickly became obvious that his intention was to add a micro-transaction store to make "gems" purchasable so that you didn't have to wait for eons between tedious button clicks. After enough stink was raised, he has now backtracked and said that he never intended for PC players to have to use the microtransactions. (We did, after all, already pay a healthy sum for this... thing.) Instead, we can now earn our gems in-game by sacrificing our builders.So for you who have not had the "pleasure" of attempting this poorly designed clickfest, let me sum it up for you:You move land around one piece, one layer, and one click at a time, taking a significant amount of effort to perform this tedious task, for the purpose of clearing enough area for a builder to place a building. However, this process quickly becomes expensive, and you have to collect "belief" from the buildings by - you guessed it - clicking each individual one. Each building is on a timer, and slowly earns this "belief" that, once earned, you can use to... Move more land.Sure, there's other "things" in the game, such as collecting "stickers" so you can put them on "cards" so you can eventually get an upgrade that would let you do something like, build bigger buildings that take longer to make belief... Or build buildings on grass instead of sand. Or collect your builders and sacrifice them for gems (you get 1 gem per, you don't have a lot of builders, and it takes them 16 minutes to replenish).Most recently added to the game is the "sailing" minigame. If you thought the rest of the game sounded pointless, you'll love this one. Your goal is to drop off a handful of "workers" on one side of an island... Then sculpt enough land that they can reach a target on the other side of the island. Enthralling...I actually muscled my way through the first round of this drivel because you have to get the cards and stickers to advance the game in any way. (Since apparently as a "God" you have some sort of Pokemon fetish.) By the time I got to round 2 (called Mountains and Meteors for those who want to give it a shot) I got through 7 levels quite easily, then hit level 8. Which I'm not even going to bother attempting to finish.In this level of the minigame, you have to drop meteors (which it's a roll of the dice what they'll do when they hit) in order to wipe out the "giants" and clear a path to the other end of the island. However, the whole system is so buggy that I'd be shocked if anyone ever managed to do it their first run through. (I was using a cheat and didn't manage to get through for hours, and finally gave up on the 5th game crash. Did I mention it's buggy?)On your boat, you have 30 "workers". You have to put a minimum of 10 down to get to the other end of the island, which gives you a maximum of 3 attempts. Fail all three (and you will... Repeatedly) and then you have to play the waiting game for "reinforcements" to attempt it again. And by the waiting game, I mean there's a SEVEN ♥♥♥♥ING HOUR TIMER. And this is still fairly early in the game! You could spend your gems at this point (you start with 100) to get an instant boost, and that'll cost you 69 gems for your first attempt. Afterward, you can burn all of your builders, turning them into gems, for your second attempt. After that, it's time to shelve the game and wait for a few hours real-time before you can attempt it again.I mean, I suppose you could go back to sculpting the land, except that all of your builders are now nuked, and you used all your belief to kill them for gems. So you can sit and twiddle your thumbs and wait until you have some more belief bubbles to pop, or you can uninstall this hunk of reconstituted dog♥♥♥♥♥♥and play something that's actually entertaining.I actually have a ♥♥♥♥ing headache as a result of trying to enjoy this game that I paid good money for.Sure, the game is still technically in alpha, but this is the third iteration of it now. And while I would never have believed it possible, each iteration is actually worse than the previous one. There's simply no direction in the game. It's not entertaining in any way, and it's exceedingly clear that the team (and by "team" I mean Peter - who refused to allow the team to do any work on the game while he was on vacation) that the "team" has one, and only one focus with this game: To figure out how to make it as boring as possible so people will purchase stuff with the microtransactions. Unfortunately, he's missing a major part to having any sort of microtransaction game be successful, and that is that first, the people have got to want to play it.This game is the equivalent of bubble wrap, but you're only given a small 6" by 6" sheet once every few hours unless you pay extra money. You can pop through your bubbles fast, or you can do them one at a time, but either way you're left with a hunk of plastic you have to throw away and then sit on your♥♥♥♥♥and wait to be handed another one.Now, all of this said, after realizing that I would have to wait another 2 hours to click another bubble, I just used a hex editor to give myself unlimited "gems" in the game so I wasn't held back by the microtransactions. And you know what? It was even more boring. Never would've thought that was possible.  Even with unlimited gems, I never was able to finish the boring♥♥♥♥♥"mini-game" mission.  Cannot recommend this game any less.  It's the last time Molyneux gets my money.  (And ignore the "hours played."  Apparently the game glitched at one point, stayed running in the background, and racked up hours even though it wasn't "visible."  Apparently it stayed there for over a week.  I've only managed to muscle through about 5 hours of actual play time.)

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Yeah, this is my first review, so it'll probably be awful, but I'm going to be brutally honest here: This waste of cash was BORING.What do I mean?  Well...there is so much micromanaging, but that's only percentage-wise.  The gameplay is EXTREMELY slow, enough to put someone to sleep.  A game about being a sky-god SHOULD NOT BE BORING.  I spent the entire first session, all 91 minutes or whatever, waiting for it to kick up its intensity even slightly.Nothing.  Black and White was better than this - B&W shoots Godus with a sniper rifle, in one eye and out the other, from a distance of about a kilometer, then does awful things to its corpse.To make it worse, the click-and-drag interface.  Oh.  Dear. GOD the interface.  A lot of people seem to be frustrated by this point, so read those reviews for more details.I would more easily recommend Dwarf Fortress - yes, THAT Dwarf Fortress - to a casual gamer, than I would this to anyone.  Heck, I enjoy DF, and I'm pretty casual.That this game is $20 USD isn't just salt in the wound.  It's more like someone put a rocksalt shot in a shotgun, put the barrel's opening directly on my right hand, and pulled the trigger.  I literally would not recommend this game for 10% of its asking price.You want a better game?  Go buy Dragon: the Game.  It's $2 cheaper than this, and while yes, it's still in development and pretty buggy, that means the developers want your input as much as your cash.  Give it to them, and don't give this developer a dime.You want another better game?  How about The Long Dark.  Same price, but much better developed, with survival in the wilds of frozen Canada and wolves trying to tear you to pieces.  It's tough, but at least it's a way better buy.You want another one?  What am I, a computer?  Go browse on your own.  You'll probably find more hits on Steam than this thing's cost in pennies.

Early Access Review
								I had high hopes for this one as a big fan of the old Populous games, and various other Peter Molyneaux creations.Unfortunately Molyneaux left the project, leaving the game in early access with a lot of development to go, and perhaps two full time developers working on it. Essentially because one quite vocal fan/community presence decided to step up and take over the project rather than allow it to be simply abandoned (credit to you, Konrad).Basically Godus is the story of a very rich man who decided to take people's money on Kickstarter to start his latest brainchild - which he could have easily funded himself - getting bored, and leaving less than half way through development. It serves as a lesson to myself and others about the dangers of early access, and a reminder of why not to trust Peter Molyneaux.

number of helpful: 10 of 13 people (77%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								I first bought this game the last time it was 50% off--back when it was a giant clickfest. It was novel for a bit, but that wore off quickly once I grew aware of the clicking and the fact that this was just a big ol' "flatten the earth to get villagers and cards to unlock more earth to flatten to get more villagers and cards" game.Now, with the recent update, there's less clicking (more click+dragging) but it's pretty much the same game, only instead of cards you collect stickers. It's the same mechanic--there's a chest under the ground, you reveal it, click it, get a sticker to apply *to* a card to unlock its bonuses (you unlock cards based on the number of villagers, and they don't get activated unless you apply the correct amount/type of stickers.) It's still pretty much a "flatten the earth for more villagers" fest, so it's easy to realize mid-play that the gameplay is stale and really quite pointless. It plays more like an android game than anything. Definitely not worth 20 bucks (I'd even say not even worth 10. 5 at most.)Other than that, I love the sound effects and art style. Shaping the land to be asthetically pleasing can be something of an art, but doing so hinders progression. It pushes the player to the mentality "I really want to shape the land to how I want, but I should progress first and do what I want later" which is a huge deterring thought most experienced gamers can become aware of almost instantly.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								I really wanted to like this game..but the only thing it really accomplished was to make me very cautious about Early Access games. I enjoyed the earlier alpha releases, but then subsequent releases removed 90% of what I enjoyed about those releases. When I watched the videos produced for each release by the developer, I got a sense of frustration from Peter Molynieux and felt like he was mostly defesndive. I began to realize something was wrong when I felt like I had been scolded after the videos. It may very well be that this game is not yet half done...but what progress has been made toward "completion" has also taken the game away from what once had me so very excited.I have enjoyed many good games from Mr. Molynieux, including Populous, which was one of my childhood favorites. I have come to expect great things from games bearing his name. Unfortunately, it isn't just that Godus isn't good...the major problem is that I feel deceived. That will be a long and painful scar that will cause me to doubt all future Early Access purchases--especially those associated with Peter Molynieux.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								Right now, this is not fun at all.It's painfully obvious how they made this a mobile centric game, and their (to me) annoying slathering of time delay mechanics infuriates me.In my opinion, time delays and and cool downs have to be the laziest game design mechanic i have ever had the displeasure of experiencing. Especially when they are needlessly added to a game to artifically extend the total play time of the game. And even more so when the intention is to hook the player so they feel the need to come back to the game after the hour long wait is over. That is a trope used by mobile games since their genesis. I do not find it fun, and Godus is filled to the brim with it.There is some potential for a great experience in this however. Unfortunatly it is burried under a mountain of problems:waiting around for things to snowball (if that ever happens).horrible pathfinding AI the followers exhibit.not being able to destroy old buildings to alow for newer better abodes.painfully slow progression (i want to be able to get reasonably far in an 2 hour play session).Voyages are not fun at all for me, i want to manage my homeworld. That's why im playing a god game. I don't want to do silly mini games meant for mobile players to gain the very basic tools to progress in the main game. Also bogged down by the crap pathfinding and clunky inconsistent sculping.The gathering rate of belief is to low, almost all my time is spent waiting or grinding in voyages to get belief just so i CAN PLAY THE MAIN GAME THAT I PAYED FOR !If these things are fixed/balanced or removed I believe i would indeed enjoy the game, because watching the followers grow, your towns grow, and your landscape grow, is all extremely cool and fun. For the PC version at least. PLEASE.Please note: theres the entire back half and end game i have not yet experienced since i can not will myself to play the game that long.

I definitely look twice at paying for games still under development now.  Thank you Godus; you inspire distrust.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is awful, time spent in the game feels like time fully wasted. It reminds me of my mortality and makes me sad that I'm spending my precious time on this earth playing this crap. And I've played it for less than 10 hours since I bought it long ago.It takes a certain type of s*** to cause that sort of hatred so quickly. And the worst thing is, that this game could have been sooooooooo ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ good. If not for the crap decisions the developers have made.I'm not just going to ramble on about all the reasons this game is terrible (but it is, don't buy the game). Instead, I'll give you a first hand experience of my thoughts on this game, from the time I bought it till now.I bought it far before the big 2.0 update (or should I say the entire scrapping and remaking of this game).That's right folks, I was there at the very beginning of this disaster. I bought this game as it mentioned it was inspired by populous, and I thought 'wow, a game inspired by Peter Molyneux's good era of games, before he became an awful game developer, and without any input by him, sounds great!'So I bought the game, and was excited at first, it wasn't bad initially, for the first 20 minutes. And then the awful AI multiplayer tutorials came on. Cringeworthy, embarrasing, pathetic. Playing with fake people, all of them tragic and worthy of some form of pity for some reason. One girl seemed to have issues with her dad, one dude was 30 and unemployed, desperate to gain fulfillment in his bleak life by getting more gems in the game.And they never ended, they went on and on and on, this pathetic illusion of multiplayer. 'Why is the game doing this? Who thought it was a good idea? Why would they make it like this? Is this the only multiplayer in the game? Will it ever end?'And then the grinding happened, which I should point out has not changed in the updates, it seems even worse now.It was at this point that I found out that good old Peter Molyneux IS involved in the game, which explains so much. He was brilliant in his time, and I have huge respect for his older games. Black and White was a masterpiece, simple as. I've loved it for years, still play it occassionally, and I firmly believe that the creature AI is yet to be outdone in a game, including it's not so good sequel.But now, Peter is the worst kind of 'maverick'. His ideas are great, but the way he implements them are terrible, TERRIBLE! And the reason is simple, there is nobody to reign him in. He is a well known figure, who's going to argue with him? They let him do what he likes, and he ♥♥♥♥s♥♥♥♥♥♥up.If they took his great ideas, and then made them fun and enjoyable with some outside help, controlled him a bit, this game would have been fantastic. But it's not, it's garbage. It has been for a looooooong time, and the countless updates have done nothing to change that.The only thing that could save it would be a complete overhaul of the game, redo it from scratch, remove the grinding, make it fun. But they won't do that, they can't, too much time has been spent on it already.I'd demand a refund if I felt there was any hope of getting it. But to be honest, it was worth buying it for the multiplayer tutorials in the past. I'm serious, they were so awkward, so awful, it was hilarious, if slightly painful to read. The type of bad that only Peter Molyneux could make.In short, don't buy this game, it's a great concept, could have been FANTASTIC, but is boring, dull, and tedious. And the worst part is, the developers f***ing know it! They have the nerve to tell you in the commentary to do other things while you wait for crap to happen.Do other things Peter eh? Like play another game? A good game? No need to tell me twice!

								The recent (2.0) improvements to Godus are superficial at best and the new tutorial insulting.I think one of the most fundamental problems is that there is no personality to your followers or their settlement. I would gladly collect belief and look for stickers if it actually meant that it created something spectacular and I could follow individual followers and their struggles to build families etc, to survive and build a civilization in a hostile world. In Godus I am not a God, I am the creator of flat surfaces. I'm basically a bulldozer that collects stickers. ﻿

number of helpful: 10 of 14 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								Godus is a game built without drama or conflict.  The only constraint you will run into is a risk of carpel tunnel as you slowly expand your influence in a dead world.  While Godus is technically a god game your followers cannot engage in any independent activity and require no food or resources to continue existing, as such there is nothing to do but keep nudging them to expand until a population cap is reached, and no constraint other than time to prevent you from reaching said cap.  It is also worth noting that while Godus states that followers are your measure of size and scope, followers do not directly create each other.  Followers instead make houses, and upon making a house they enter it and never again exit.  After a certain amount of time passes you can click on a house and get a new follower from it, and thus continue to expand your empire to houses.Godus also features the ability to reshape the terrain.  While this can be fun, it lacks the visceral feel of performing the same action in a game like Minecraft and uses an interface for this that is less engaging than the one found in the original Magic Carpet.  Rather than using dramatic spells or a slow change from a low level by means of follower activity Godus chooses to have you raise and lower the terrain by means of double clicking.  I kickstarted this game, and unfortunately it did not deliver.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a freemium game for the ios and android but is being charged a fee to play it on the pc. Well... I should clarify that. they removed the ability to buy stuff from the pc game but they left all of the stuff in there that is designed to slow down the game so that you buy stuff. very strange.... for example... I'm now waiting a few hours for some stuff to build.This is the only game where I am glad to be interrupted while playing it because that means something will be done when I come back to the game.Hopefully they remove all the painful delays from the game when it leaves early access.Update: Ok. I've had some time to play the game and I'm now able to look beyond my overwhelming frustration with the time delay to provide some more feedback. (sort of able to look past it)Pros:1. I really like the look of the game2. I also like how they let you model the land to build stuff on it. I think they got that one down pretty good.3. I like how you have to grown your population to unlock stuffCons:1. I HATE HATE HATE HATE HATE HATE having to wait 3 days for something to be built. And that is what the timer says. 3 days. it actually takes even longer then that because your workers take naps. So it will probably be 4 or 5 days. I'm going to do a few minor things in the game then I don't expect to ever play it again unless there are some radical changes in the wait time.2. I hate all of the stupid, pointless resources. you have belief which lets you build some stuff. Then you have to get wheat to build other stuff and then you have to get ore to build other stuff and then you have to have gems to do other things. So you end up having to create this huge infrastructure of ore to be able to unlock to portals and once they are unlocked they don't do anything.3. This game wins for being the most frustrating game I have ever played.4. So there is this In-Game game where you have to get your followers to go from one point to another point on a map. It makes me so mad because you can't control your followers and they are idiots. Oh and did I tell you it is timed. So you have to get your followers to go from point a to point b in a very short time frame with no control over them and things are trying to kill them and you have limited resources. Fun... it is not.5. Oh yeah. so my theory that they took the free game from the ios and brought it to the pc was confirmed. They forgot to remove a button from the pc version which, when you click on it, tells you to buy gems at the store... except for the pc version doesn't have a store so... yeah... Conclusion: If they got rid of the wait times and balanced out the other stuff I think I could recommend this game... right now where the game is there is no way I would ever recommend it.Oh yeah my hours into this game are so big because I just leave it running in the background. It is a easy way to build up resources.Update 2:Ok They just released a new balance option which is AWESOME. It lets you eliminate a majority of the stupid timers so that the game is actually fun. So here is the deal.I would actually recommend this game if the balance options, which allow you to speed up the timers, stay in the game. However, I'm under the impression that they are going to remove them once the game gets more developed. At that point I think the game will go from being awesome to sucking.I actually came into this review specifically to update my review to be a recommend when, as I was typing, I realized that they probably are going to remove the balance options and then I'd have to update my review again. I'm just going to leave it as a not recommend until I get more concrete info that the stupid timers are going to stay in seconds rather then days.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Godus, so far below par.Having played the game on and off for the last few days, and currently at about the 12 hour mark of playtime, I can tell you that the game has a lot of potential.A lot of the 'early' parts of the game are fleshed out well, and seem quite polished, however the 'middle' part of the game is about expansion and landscaping two things that are not very exciting, and often I find myself expanding because increasing population gives small rewards.It is very difficult to unlock the cards needed for technological advancement, and it is not really something that you can affect, the 'treasure chest' mechanic feels random and un-rewarding.Currently the game has many glitches and difficulties. It is SOOOO tedious to reshape the landscape, and it often does not reshape the way you want it to resulting in people getting stuck everywhere. The Astari (rival tribe) also gain loads of happiness and beat your tribe whenever you save and leave your PC for more than a few hours, even when their entire kingdom is covered in swamp land and they all die every time they leave their houses. If you win people from rivals they do nothing but annoy you for the entire game.Overall it is a wonderful looking game, with a lot of potential, but can't help but think the PC is an after thought for the developers, and it will all be about buying gems on a mobile phone. I have had some fun playing it up until this point. I would not recommend paying full price for this game while it is in Early Access, however it could easily be worth the full price when the game is finished.My recommendation would be to pick up any Civilization game, because while this game looks super cute, right now Civilization does everything this game does better!

								For some reason, the Godus team thinks that people enjoy waiting long periods of time for buildings, mana regen, etc to finish. They must have looked at games like EA's Dungeon Keeper for iOS and say "Hey, we can do a game like that, but without (currently) any real money transactions. We'll still keep the awkward in game currency and still make players wait around for arbitrary amounts of time. Hours even. We'll make it so they play for only 20 minutes at a time and then wait an hour for stuff to finish.. Brilliant!"Molyneux..... You've fooled me for the last time. I'm done. You'll never get another dime from me. Everyone, please stay away and stop falling for his money traps. If it didn't come from Bullfrog Productions, it's just a waste of time and money.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								DO NOT BUY!Godus isn't merely incomplete, it's a game with no gameplay. Despite being "over 50% done" the game still shows no signs of a solid mechanical core or idea, and the terrible progression systems and heavily gated resources only serve to mask the fact that there's very little to do even when treating it as a zen-sandbox. There's no megastructures or sweeping vistas to build because, almost ironically for a god game, the game only lets you destroy. You can erode, flatten, and homogenize, but never build. The only real avenue of challenge is waiting, and "progressing" through the game only makes this "challenge" worse. Rather than progression being a way to overcome old challenges and open up new challenges, advancing through the tech timeline only adds a new coat of paint to the waiting game, often adding hours, or days, to the time it takes to gather new resources.Additionally the game's sparse mechanics are broken with almost insulting ease. Gems, the pay-to-win currency of the mobile version, are so powerful that the "cost" of sacrificing followers to the Pit of Doom is entirely offset by the things bought with the resulting gems.The game will not get better because it isn't a game yet. If they haven't figured out what the gameplay is by the 50% mark then they probably never will.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								A man cannot serve two masters.  Godus as it stands has too much tablet DNA to be a decent PC game.  This is a real shame, as there are some wonderful concepts there that can't quite get out.I've like Peter Molyneux games since the beginning.  Godus is similar to Black and White in that the interaction with the world is very different to a standard PC strategy game.  This isn't a bad thing.  The lack of direct control, the interaction with the landscape, even the treasure hunt aspects are all really interesting and work well together.  But the problem lies in the execution.  It is very difficult to play this game for more than 15-20 minutes without running out of things to do.  On a mobile game, that's fine.  For a PC game, it's frustrating.  The reason for this is that everything is based on real world time, so if a beacon is going to take 16 hours to build, you shut the game down and come back in 16 hours.  Again, this is standard for a mobile game, and there are justifications for it in a social game as well I guess, but it means there is a lot of dead time.  Much more dead time than actual fun time.The shame is, I enjoy playing the game.  The land sculpting and bringing together settlements is really well done and a lot of fun.  But normally after 5 minutes, just when I'm getting into it, I'm out of belief.  Then there's 5 minutes of hunting chests, maybe go on a voyage, but really there's nothing to do but close the program and wait a couple of hours.As I say, the land scuplting aspect, coupled with the lovely minimalist artwork, really is lovely and interesting.  The landscape is beautiful, although it's something of a shame that your main interaction with it is to turn it into a flat parking lot to put houses up.  There is promise here, I will continue playing.  But at the moment I could not recommend this to anyone else.

content:
Posted: January 4
Early Access Review
								Godus is one of the most disapointing things in my steam library. You may be like- but mate, you have 98 hours in the game how can any game you spent 98 hours playing be BAD? Because in those 98 hours I would estimate about 10min was spent playing the game, while the rest was spent with it literally just being there in the background. I would say this game might as well have been an idle game but honestly even idle games have more gameplay, growth and content then this pile. The main error with this game is that they started with a vision- a vision of making a bad free to play mobile game... so they did. The end. The game promised massive things but delivered what amounts to a pea on a plate. It will never get finished so don't waste your time.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Godus, so far below par.Having played the game on and off for the last few days, and currently at about the 12 hour mark of playtime, I can tell you that the game has a lot of potential.A lot of the 'early' parts of the game are fleshed out well, and seem quite polished, however the 'middle' part of the game is about expansion and landscaping two things that are not very exciting, and often I find myself expanding because increasing population gives small rewards.It is very difficult to unlock the cards needed for technological advancement, and it is not really something that you can affect, the 'treasure chest' mechanic feels random and un-rewarding.Currently the game has many glitches and difficulties. It is SOOOO tedious to reshape the landscape, and it often does not reshape the way you want it to resulting in people getting stuck everywhere. The Astari (rival tribe) also gain loads of happiness and beat your tribe whenever you save and leave your PC for more than a few hours, even when their entire kingdom is covered in swamp land and they all die every time they leave their houses. If you win people from rivals they do nothing but annoy you for the entire game.Overall it is a wonderful looking game, with a lot of potential, but can't help but think the PC is an after thought for the developers, and it will all be about buying gems on a mobile phone. I have had some fun playing it up until this point. I would not recommend paying full price for this game while it is in Early Access, however it could easily be worth the full price when the game is finished.My recommendation would be to pick up any Civilization game, because while this game looks super cute, right now Civilization does everything this game does better!

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
Early Access Review
								Peter Molyneux stated in press and various media before the release of this early access that updates would be completed on a weekly basis. In the several months since then, there has been one feature-adding update, and one bug-fixing update. This, and many other Steam Early Access games, essentially amount to scams. The game itself is interesting and fun, and it has the *potential* for greatness, but it's not likely to come to fruition in any reasonable amount of time at this point. I regret buying into the hype. If you do decide to buy this game, wait until it's completely done and let these guys find funding other than through Steam purchases.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								I used to look up to Peter Molyneux.  I was once a fan.  He created some amazing games back in the day - Populous, Dungeon Keeper, Magic Carpet, Black & White, Fable - to name but a few.But these days it seems he has sold out.  After complaining about EA's interpretation of Dungeon Keeper  (a mobile phone version that employs 'pay to play' limitations), Peter has done it himself - he was created a mobile phone game for the PC that is severely crippled unless you pay - and keep on paying - to make it playable.Offering a 'pay to play' game after the user has already forked out £14.99 is dispicable.  This game was originally fun in the Alpha phase, but is now a shallow attempt to relieve the player of his or her money.Shame on you, Peter Molyneux - I was once a fan, but will never entertain the idea of buying another of your games.Uninstalling.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
Early Access Review
STAY AWAY!I had very high hopes for Godus, with the persistant world promises and actual civilization building á la populous meets settlers. However this is nothing but false promises or broken mechanics, at best. The whole game is a complete and utter disappointment, possibly the worst let down I've ever been served by mr. Molyneux - and I've played all his titles.It's nothing but a pay-to-wait game with a premium price-tag slapped on top to really milk every cent from your pockets. They've introduced a gem-shop (that they claim will never be charging actual money.... yeah, right). I don't want to spend half the cost of a AAA-title to sit around and NOT PLAY THE GAME while waiting for all these idiotic timers to tick down. No, it's just not 5 minutse or 10 minutes here and there, EVERY SINGLE BUILDING is blocked by timers that can stretch upwards 24 HOURS. I have 12 hours on record on steam, with a good 30 piled into it in offline mode. Even after my first 6 hours of playing, I ended up in a situation where I could do nothing but WAIT for an hour until I could continue playing the game. Further developing my settlement took me a WEEK OF WAITING within my initial 20 hours of total play time!There is absolutely NO reason what so ever to buy this game, or even look at this steam store page. THEY DO NOT DESERVE YOUR TIME. The mere fact that you're reading this is bad enough. MOVE ALONG!DONOTBUY

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Godus – a game that you buy to play it 10 minutes per day. Because it does not let you play it when you want to play it.Godus is fun for the first 30 minutes. Building a small village, collecting belief, sculpting the landscape and playing little mini-games can be fun. But after that you need to expand and you want to create bigger settlements.Well, too bad … it takes 20 minutes to complete a single building. Belief generation takes even longer. Later in game you also need to farm wheat to be able to create buildings. That is where the fun begins. Wheat takes up to several days until it can be harvested.After two hours your gameplay is as following: Start the game, collect belief, collect all the wheat and build as many as five new buildings with it. Wait for the next day to repeat that process.It feels like a mobile game, with the same amount of waiting. It is pure cheekiness that this game was ever released for PC.Stay away.
