content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is not worth buying. If you think this is gonna be a game where you build some kind of empire or civilization you're only half right. This game is a more complex version of Simon says. You can't decide where any of the buildings go and the people just walk around waiting for you to move something so they have more space to build stuff. I think the idea behind this game allows the player to see the world from the perspective of a god, but the only way that can work is if you have first hand control of everything that is going on and in this case you don't. I understand that this game isnt finished yet, but the way I see it, this game needs to be completly remade to work. I firmly do not recommend this game.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Godus at this stage of development is a deeply disappointing waste of code that that utterly fails to live up to the promise of its creator. Godus is a tediously slow game and by far the worst creation associated with Peter Molyneux's  name. The game is achingly slow to progress due an obnoxious pay-or-wait mechanic identical to that which infests mobile gaming; the very same mechanic that Molyneux complained about in the mobile conversion of Dungeon Keeper. More gallingly, the Godus devs insultingly try to paint this abhorrent mechanic as a positive feature that allows players more freedom rather than something that ruins the flow of the game and degrades it into nothing but a Skinner Box.

Early Access Review
								Simple graphics and interesting mechanics belie a game that has been abandoned by its authoring studio. with virtually no contact from developers to customers beyond "we're still working" notes on twitter, Godus remains firmly in the Alpha stage for the forseeable future. if 22cans is still working on this game, nobody has seen any evidence of it since october 2013. number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
Early Access Review
								After another update, this game continues to disapoint, timers are insanely long. The Astari, are the most annoying feature that anyone could dream up, everything in this game is designed to force you to log in every few hours. The designers seem to think that my PC is a damn IPad, this is not the game they promised during their kickstarter campaign.I will continue to try out the new features, but i am certain it will continue to be a joke of a game.Very little has changed from below, except they have put more blocks in place of your enjoyment.After having high hopes with the new patch i gave godus 2.0 another go, i really wish i had not bothered.now instead of too much clicking its click and drag, click and drag. Dull, boring mechanics make this game a chore to play, there is no point in progressing, the more powerful you become the more clicking and dragging you have to do. The ridiculous sticker system, that replaced the previous resource system is a total joke, it changes nothing you just have a little more freedom in which totaly pointless upgrade you can have for your villagers. Homelessness and lost villagers are a pointless addition, they never seem to die, so who the hell cares if they are homeless. Sculpting is slightly better, but still a chore, everything takes too long, why cant i sculpt more than one level at a time? Maybe i get the ability in the future, but i will never find out as i will wait till there is another major update before attempting this game again.Voyages, another totaly pointless addition, if i wanted to play lemmings i would play lemmings. Why the hell would i as a god, need to sculpt a path to a temple that exsists on another land mass for no reason what so ever. in 25 seconds??  It`s another chore especially when your villagers are so dumb they can not manage to go up a clearly accessable path until you make it slightly wider and then some still can not manage it.What ever you do, do not buy this game, if it interests you then wait for another major update. It is not worth any amount of money yet.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Click....clickclickclick....click....click and drag.....click...clickclickclick.  I normally love these types of games, I totally adore Molyneux and I'd been eagerly following this since Kickstarter.  It's not really showing any potential in the actual content anymore.The graphics are pretty and remind me of "From Dust".  I only played it for half an hour but my wrist can't take anymore.  My minions don't do anything but hide in their houses and come out when i poke them to build more, I can't even choose where they build.  The pop ups for the cards is irritating and overall you are left feeling rather adrift, haunted by the infernal noise of your own clicking.  I want to say happy things about this game but unfortunately all I can say is its visually appealing while you give yourself carpal tunnel.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								I wouldn't recommend the game, not because its a bad game, i wouldn't call it a good game, but definitely not a bad game, its distracting is probably the best compliment i can give.In it, you attempt to grow your civilization by making them nice flat land to build houses on.  Almost all of your interaction with the game involved flattening land, it does get a bit boring, especially since all of your villagers and their houses are more or less identical (there are different tech levels of buildings, but nothing at each tech level to make anything stand out).  There isn't any kind of personal feel, and you don't really have anything to do with your villagers except gather belief from them.The ui is also a bit wonky, i call it a reverse port when i think about it.  The game was obviously meant to be released on tablets, its a bit odd that they released on pc first, it takes full advantage of all the niceties of using a touchscreen, but makes no effort to cater to those of us using a mouse/keyboard.  It feels kind of like PC was an afterthought, even though it was released here first.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Right now, this game has nothing to do with the Populus you played 25 years ago. It's a click orgy and feels like was developed for tablets only. There are no menues of any kind, so you have to learn mouse-gestures - no support for the right mouse button either! It feels very much like it was developed for tablets only.The game pace is terrible slow. Most of the time you will just sit around and waiting for the pink bubbles (your mana points, which allow you to do things like terra forming etc.) to pop up above each of your settlements, which you then have to collect by clicking on them. Let me repeat that: if you have 200 settlements, you have to click 200 different pink bubbles to collect your "mana points" and progress in the game. So most of the time you end up just sitting around doing nothing and just wait for the next bubbles to click on, which is as much fun as watching paint dry - except that paint will dry much faster than this game progresses. It's just a huge disapointment for me. Save your money or pick up the original Populus on GOG instead.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								I just thought I'd come back to this review, edit it, and still warn people to stay away. Even now, a year later, after all these updates, this game is nothing but a horrendous cash-grab.I just want to start off by saying that 22Cans has decided to use your money you invested in Godus, to fund a new game. Yes, not only did they use your Funds before to fund their Tablet pay2win version of Godus, they're essentially giving up on both and funding a new game. This game is rarely updated, when it is, its nothing even worth mentioning. The Developers rarely respond or listen, it appears the only threads they will respond to are negative threads.About the game itself. It is essentially a village and landscaping simulator. You manage your villagers and landscape the terrain so everything is flat so your villagers can expand. They generate faith which appear and purple bubbles on their houses which you must click to collect. The entire game is clicking, you have to click on houses to make villagers come out, click on faith bubbles, click on terrain, trees, rocks. When the game first came out, the more you play it the more you see they made it to compliment a touch-screen tablet. While they denied this, guess what happened... A tablet version of the game comes out, which gets more developer attention than the PC.While you're doing all this clicking and expanding your villages you unlock god powers. You're thinking, awesome, Populous. No, these god powers are expensive, boring, and do really do anything to help you at all, they just compliment your village expansion and clicking abilities.We were originally promised a civilization game where you would expand into space age. They have just stated that they downsized their team to fund and develop their new game because they are almost done with Godus.. Well, its been this long as we only have 2 ages, were not even out of Before-Christ eras yet. Say goodbye to Space age, it will never happen.They originally promised us an earth-like planet where everyone else would be connected to and playing. They said you could be randomly sculpting your land, then suddently run into another god and their civilization. You could make war with them, or joing them and build together. This is no longer happening. I cant imagine how many people were scammed because they bought the game solely for this. I bought the game solely for this, because honestly, I wanted to wreck stuff with my god powers. Now we get "Hub-Worlds" where you'll essentially battle against a few other gods at super speed. Basically match-making games that will end and return you back into your singleplayer game.I seriously advice anyone to stay far from this game.

								The game that soured me on Kickstarter. Simply: It's a free to play/pay to progress game. Unfortunately, it was presented on Kickstarter as a traditional game, everyone's money collected, before it was revealed that you pretty much have to pay to progress in the in game store.If you want to do a free to play/pay to progress, fine, make that. But give that away for free and make your money from its paywalls. Don't sell it to people as a traditional, playable game, collect their money and then pull a bait and switch.Don't waste your money buying it now. number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								So this is me now re-reviewing this game after it's re-regenisis. Having a considerable amount of hours put into (pre and post re-release), I would like to think that I have a justified conclusion about where I stand with the game now and 22cans.So, firstly, the pro's. Yes, it's been revamped. We now don't have to click as much, in fact, little to none. We click and drag. The population now has a bit of charm and mobility, creating friendships and being active around the world, and the voyage quests put a breathe of fresh air into the game. This is, however, meant with some poor AI and pathing problems, and a general lack of pace.Belief now struggels to get into the 10,000 mark whilst sculpting, and although the bottom layers (sand under water and on land to the first grassy layers) are free, it simply isn't enough to continue scultping as you will, like the original release of the game.Belief was always a major problem for myself, I think it's the most boring resource collection in any God game. This was felt unanimously in the early access community, but instead of the mechanic being altered, we are now propted to do it differently. With the clicking and the dragging. Followers get lost, dazed and confused constantly, and a recent update doesn't seem to tackle the issue, but prompt you to look at them. A beacon will flash continuously, over and over again, alerting the player to simply look at them. The update has not fixed the issue of poor AI, but instead taunts the player to attempt to sculpt steps adlib with the previously stated little to none belief that can be collected. The poor AI also leads to some horribly frustrating incidents aside from step scultping.The voyage quest are, as I stated at the start, a nice feature but the poor pathing issues lead to incidents that leave the player gobsmacked at the utter stupidity of his believers. Numerous times have I created a lovely path for my bold travelers to safety and victory, only to look back at there progress witnesses them entering a wall of death in a swamp. Or whatever that little black, spotty bit of land is called. I have no doubt that a new update will have tutorials and directional arrows to your destination, however. The common theme of this update is a general ignorance from 22cans to realise the true problems fans and customers are having with the game. "The beliefe mechanic is a bad mechanic as it prompts to player to click too much and has no depth whatsoever to the game", the Steam community would say. To which 22cans would say "Ah, we'll click and drag".The biggest critque of this re-review is 22cans itself and inabilty to connect with the early access community in order to develope a game that was worth the money in the first place. Putting your head in the sand whilst everything goes wrong and not communicating for 3 months is at the very least an immature way to create a game, or in a broader context, to handle a market. In a day of where I can communicate with a friend in the States, Australia or Japan from my humble house near Glasgow, I feel a lack of communication has no excuss. Clicking causes stress on the joints, but dragging is a drag.Buy if you wish, but I've uninstalled.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
Early Access Review
 Are you looking to pay $20 for the Simpons Tapped Out? If so, then look no further.How is this game like Simpsons Tapped Out?In the STO you collect money from towns people.  In Godus you collect belief from followers.  Belief == MoneyOnce you get enough money, in STO you build buildings that collect large sums of money at an easily tappable location.  Likewise in Godus,once you collect enough Belief, you create Settlements that gather large amounts of Belief in an easily tappable location.In the STO you have to complete towns people missions in order to gain XP to advance through the levels.  In Godus, you need to use followers to complete "missions" in order to unlock resources and land expansions that enable you to advance through the ages.All of this is extremely tedious if playing on PC, which I'll assume you plan to do, given this is the Steam forums.Add to this the lack of developer feedback/interaction with the community, the lack of regular game updates, and the censorship of the game forums (particularly when the game is on sale), and you have a game that should not even be listed on Steam, let alone one you should consider buying.[tldr;] Godus should be a free to play mobile/tablet game.

content:

Early Access Review
								Do not buy into this game. You will be "empowered" to be the most lame excuse of ground-levelling god so your followers can decide to build things you have no say in. There is almost next to no control over your followers and progression is painfully slow and unrewarding. It takes a little more than digging for a stupid card to keep me interested. The "regular updates" the developer promised are so slow, it's almost a joke.  I bought this for 9.99$ during the Steam Winter sale, and regret every penny of it.0 cans out of 22 cans, shameful display, and I feel dumb for falling for the developer's PR bait on YouTube and online.UPDATE: The mobile title has been released, with typical P2W mechanics we all see in other titles. So much for "aesthetic" microtransactions, eh?  I regret backing this game, and every time I try to play it, it only stays on my computer for an hour before I fear for my sanity, so I delete it again.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game, still in beta, is probably not worth the $$ you'll spend on it at this time. Virtually no in-game documentation to help you learn what it is you need to do to start can lead to a complete loss of "faith" before you get to the point in the game where your followers start generating it for you. There is no in-game way to quit and start over (you have to delete your saves files), and there some goofy scripted "p-v-p" battle zone that is actually player vs AI battle zone. Additionally, once an area is cleared, there is no way to put trees or other beautiful things back into it and lots of times the silly followers will start building as soon as an area is available instead of waiting for me to finish.  I wish there was a "building" menu for me to select from the different buildings that my followers know how to usein order for me to more beautifully place my buildings. I guess I thought it would be more like SIMS and less like click, drag, pull and hope for the best.  Oh and like others said, lots and lots of random clicking. I wish there were preiests who could go to outlying places and "collect" the faith for me, so that then I just needed to click on the wandering bubble of faith, or the priest would go every 10 minutes or so and deposit faith in a church or temple.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								(This applies to version 1.3.1 of the game, and may hopefully one day prove invalid when an improved game comes along. No luck so far though).Avoid this disappointing dull click-fest that goes nowhere.Peter Molyneux, who created some of the best games I've ever played, should be able to do better than this. The game, in its present form, is shockingly unengaging and crashy, even for a beta. It's tedious beyond words and has been given an early beta release before even basic elements of the interaction or incentives of playing seem to have been considered. Don't expose yourself to the boring and shoddy half-finished work of someone whose previous titles were great. Wait. And hope it gets better somehow.

content:

Early Access Review
								There are many reasons why I am saying I wouldn't recommend this game, one being that it is clearly over hyped and not living up to any expectations.  I will admit though I do keep playing it.  You may wonder why I am playing a game if I think it is not worth recommending. Well to start I have nothing against cow clickers, I do have something against paying for one, this is a game that one should not have to pay for at all.  If one is to pay for it one should not pay full price, get when it is on a sale if you must see what it is like.  I got it during a steam sale myself. I still feel I may have over paid.I do however see the potentail this game has, I do however have doubt that such potenial shall be reached.  I also must admit that this is not a game for all people, I some how enjoy it.  Mind you I am normally enjoying some wine or beer while playing it, thus making use of the mindlessness it is in full.  Hardly use my brain power but am able to suck myself in to my computer for hours.I do wonder why I still bought this game even after seeing so many people not recommend this game, then I realized I never take good advice. In long, if you like to take risks, buy the game.  If you like good games that require thinking and full use of your mind look else where.  Now I must go click little pink balls some more and mine stuff that is totally useless.I should have just bought Starbound....

content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Ive only just begun to play but I already find the game to be incredibly charming and relaxing to play. Its ssimple and easy to get into, the graphics are very nice to look at (very colorful) and its easy to lose yerself for hours as you take care of your little beleivers.However its still clearly an Early Acess game--shaping the land can be difficult and incredibly touchy at best; I really think some environmental music could really make the experience completely enveloping; and in-game goals can be diluted and vague, making it uncertain what youre actually aiming to do--but ultimately didnt find these lackings to be deal breakers. I had and still have fun playing this game but I wouldnt rec it unless you enjoy that facebook game feel.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								Was an awesome idea, had this game for years, checked in on it, wondering wehy nothing seems to have changed much, after reading the forums it's clear  the developers used the PC version of Godus as bait to pay for the initial investment in their 'free to play' mobile micro transaction game. Which explains a lot now. The game itself was quite nice, back then, as it showed great pootential. But now, just another abandoned Early Access scam, I don't know why anyone even purchases an EA title anymore. Hopefully Steam will likewise change some of their TOS to enable these kind of drawn out and pseudo abandoned games to be removed from steam. I would avoid this title as it's nothing liek it was intended and basically just a terraforiming farm sim now...and not a very good one.

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
Early Access Review
								Steer clear of this game!  (For now)If you've played Populous series which made by the same dev and think it's gonna be its successor, think again.Imagin you put Populous as a base game and stripped everything that made the series enjoyable out of it.  Yep, you get Godus.  Plain and simple.The game has one home-world. No shaman for you.  and to do something you need to generated god power by waiting. I'm not talking about 10-30 seconds waiting in Populous. It's more like in some social media games (Face**cough) and you have to *PICK IT UP ONE BY ONE WITH YOUR HAND*To build a building you have to wait 5 mins for the smallest building.  You can speed things up with more followers or *CASH*.  And your followers can't be outside for too long or they're DEAD. except you build a power node which cause powers and only one can be built at a time.  The game is 40% of what the dev's planned.  (If you believe them)  If you're interested I'd say wait for some hugh improvements that need to be made before buying this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Sadly this game has taught me to avoid Kickstarter or Early Access in future.  The original pitch promised 'The Regenesis of the God Game'.  It was pitched first as a desktop game, with stretch goals to support mobile, and then we were told that it would be seamless across all platforms, but what have we got?  An f2p click-fest totally unsuited to a desktop platform.  Nothing in this game even remotely matches the promise in the original pitch:"During GODUS’s development there will be many instances where specific decisions need to be taken and choices made. As a valued supporter we see you as part of the Project, so you’ll be able to suggest, comment and vote to determine many elements of the game. As you’ll discover, designing games is intriguing."So, when's that going to happen then?There has been no communication from the developers for months, though we were promised weekly updates.Many people backed this game at a higher level to include multiple copies of the game to get it on desktop and mobile platforms, only to find it's going to be free to play..If ever there was an example of how *not* to launch a crowdfunding project this is it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Time Played: 16hrsIt's a beautiful-looking game as you can see in the screenshots, and it's a beta so there's tons of functionality that's yet to be made available. I understand and could forgive that if it weren't for one detail: the controls are AWFUL!To sculpt the land you have to peel one layer, maybe 3 square cm at a time. I've recently unlocked a card that'll allow me to do 3 layers at a time with presumably a slightly larger area (I hope!), but I've not found the stickers to activate it yet (one of the bugs: the glowy effect to indicate a chest has disappeared). There's another card later on that allows me to sculpt 8 layers at a time but I'd guess that's a good 100hrs away still. Then beyond that is another card that allows 9 layers.To put that into perspective .. as far as I can tell layers go from -18 (below sea level) to +44 (above sea level) ... at least, that's the range I've seen so far. The highest I can currently build in is layer #16, so high ground has to be be levelled at least that far ... 1 layer, 3 square centimetres at a time! Landscaping is starting to get a bit tedious ...Oh! Also the further you are from sea level, the more Belief it takes to sculpt the earth, so forget trying to level that mountain until you're many hours into the game!Talking of Belief, this is generated constantly but has to be periodically harvested from your followers' buildings. This again gets fairly boring and is worse than it sounds ... since it's so costly and time-consuming to sculpt the terrain you'll find your followers sprawl further across the landscape as time passes. Right now at 16hrs it takes 10 seconds (I timed it!) to scroll from the top to the bottom of my region, but I can just about see one side to the other in a single screen. Harvesting all my Belief takes just over a minute (I have ~220 buildings atm).If they can just make the controls more friendly and less tedious they'll improve the game considerably.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								So, Godus.If my memory is correct, this is the first game I bought when i first entered Stony Brook University as an international students. I used to spend most of my weekends on it, watching my little followers living great lives. After the first semester I have declared my major and the major department moved me into many difficult courses as requirement (for example organic chemistry;Search the "CHE 321 Stony Brook" online, it is so difficult that i somehow find it amazing: how can people overcome it), and i deleted this little so i can stuff more lecture videos in my laptop. In the winter break in 2014 i find myself having too much spare time so i installed this game again on my laptop. And i was impressed! The makers have modified so many items (like combine little house togethers, attacking the hostile village using meteors and mining system), most of them are great, but some of them like the expedition using a little ship system, really suck. Though many modifications have been made, it is still in "early access" category (the game "Planet Anhilliation", which used to be in the "early access" in the same time as "Godus", have benn officially released a long time ago).But the reputation of this game has fallen a lot, it used to be in the "Feature Items" list! Now it got an "User Reviews" as "Mostly Negative" for many reasons: boring game mode, premature system, a lot of bugs...I don't think i will recommend this game, it represents a really great idea, within such a premature system. The only thing I hope now is that it can get better so next time i check on this game, i can confidently recommend this game to my friends.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								I had extreme high-expectations of this game! And Oh no, I was not disproved. My expectations where met with flowing graphics ands gameplay and smart AI manoeuvring around the land, b.e.a.u.t.i.f.u.l.But then I started to re-think this, the game caused me to start again, after my first world which I crawled across the ground to achieve, reached their bug and had to restart, (Their bug being an entrapment stopping people from playing the game too much so they can still "enjoy" it, notice the ""...)So that's my first attempt over and done with, not much I can do? Sure, let's move on.Second attempt at the game:Did good, got past where I was from my first attempt after an entire day of slavery, to then discover 'The Pit Of Doom' now ofcourse the game is "balanced" once again, notice the ""- After sacrificing about 10 people, later into the game I was hooped into a Catch 22, which I could not leave, and ultimately lost. Need gems to get hapiness? use your people, that you can't control, because you don't have belief, because they've left your houses, because you don't have enough gems...See the problem?THIRD ATTEMPT:Okay, third attempt, here we go; what can go wrong this time right?So I've got past where I was in the prior attempts, yes, it was enjoyable in the mere 10 minutes I had not played after slavering 10 hours to get back to my point where I died before..."There's things in the mountains you should try and discover!"-Okay, let's give that a go. ...And no. There IS NO CAMERA FUNCTION! I've tried 60+ minutes trying to slice an edge of a mountain, an edge. A freaking edge. and there is a massive mountain to remove, it's not possible, not, possible. They've released the Patch to add 'The pit Of Doom' but cannot add a camera function? Please, call that a patch? I call it making the game harder to play.So, the game isn't completeable hardly, it takes many hours to even attempt, it doesn't have it's replayability as it says. Oh and, well- did I mention you'll get far and then be forced to re-try?--------------------------The bottom line is, get far in the game, well done; you'll still have to retry when they patch it again, or? Complain like me and get stuck? Bottom line is you'll still have to retry it all when they patch it again.See the pattern here?--------------------------P.SI'm listening to all this "commentary" and well, they're always saying "You've always got things to do! never a need to just leave the game"-Well then, what happens when I'm building my abodes, going on a adventure thing, and they die, and now I'm waiting 1 hour for people to arrive at the boat, during that 1hour, what, the freaking hell, do, I, DO.------------------------------------------P.P.S -If I knew all of this,I wouldn't of purchased the game!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 22, 2013
Early Access Review
								Previously I'd given this game a thumbs up. A few months ago it was pretty fun. You terraformed terrain, expanded your civilization, and amassed belief from your minions to do cool things. But it's become apparent recently that 22cans is not designing a PC game. They're designing a mobile game, and releasing it on PC so they can charge people up front to fund the mobile version.Have you played one of those mobile games where you start out building things and everything is fun, and then by the second day everything takes 4 hours to complete and you can pay to speed it up? And then by the third day everything takes a week to complete? Yeah, that's what Godus is now. You can get "gems" which are a special currency that allows you to, you guessed it, speed things up.The progression system is absurd now. You progress by unlocking cards. And then buying the cards. That's right after you unlock the card you have the privilege of buying it. With stickers. That you receive when you A. buy them with gems, B. get lucky opening chests or C. play the tedious voyage minigame (more below).You know that game you were playing, called Godus? I don't think you really wanted to play that game. I mean, you said you did, but I decided you were going to play lemmings. I mean, go off and play this minigame called "Voyages", which is essentially lemmings. If you win you get stickers! If you lose then your lemmings die and you have to wait a few hours to try again. Or you can just buy the stickers with gems. When you really just wanted to play Godus.In a previous alpha there was a pseudo-PvP feature where you'd build a small civilization head-to-head against an opponent and then get some goodies when you finished it. That was great! It was a microcosm of Godus in a self-contained bubble. But now that's gone and replaced by lemmings. Honestly, if I wanted that I'd just go play lemmings.So, Godus has jumped the shark. I'm pretty sure we all should have seen it coming, since Peter Molyneux has done this a dozen times before. But it's pretty disappointing since Godus USED TO BE FUN. And now has been ruined. Probably forever.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Godus is the biggest regret of a purchase I have ever made (as far as video games are concerned, at least, but it's pretty high up there for money spent on♥♥♥♥♥♥.Firstly, had I actually been aware of Molyneux's reputation, I wouldn't have touched the damn thing with a 10ft pole. His RPS interview reads like a whiny child got caught doing something bad, and when attempts to reprimand him and hold him responsible are made, he alternates between denying everything, admitting fault and trying to guilt people into feeling bad for him, and accusing the accusers of being horrible, spiteful people. This is the pattern of an emotionally manipulative jerk, and I have zero tolerance for people like that. I wish I had never handed him a cent.The game is late, broken, missing features, has no fun mechanics at all, and feels like a huge waste of time. In fact, that's the only reason I have so many hours logged (and boy do I wish I was doing some other time-wasting activity for that massive chunk of my life.), because I had nothing left to do and needed a mindless time-waster to occupy myself with while I zoned out and tried not to think very hard about anything.I really did want to like Godus. I love terraforming games (the multiplayer map from Wesnoth that has terraforming, for example, is my favorite of all the maps and gameplay modes available, and I still find myself going back to Minecraft every once in awhile for something a little more simple.) and this promises terraforming. Does it give me that? Sorta. I guess. With a catch. With several catches, actually. You can only terraform if you unlock these collectables and collect this collectable from these collectables made by those collectables, and collect those collectables to unlock more collectables and so on and so on and so on.Call it Sticker Collection Simulator: 3015 (because that's when the game will finally ♥♥♥♥ing be done, if they don't abandon it outright first) and that would be a more honest and accurate title for this complete pile of garbage.Do not buy it. Do not think hopeful thoughts about it. If you ever see Molyneux so much as sniff in the direction of a game you think you would like, run screaming as fast as your strangely shaped nerd legs can carry you in the opposite direction and pray it never finds you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								I generally resist writing reviews for "early access games,"  but I've seen enough of the Godus development process to decide that I don't like where it's going.  The gameplay is generally very, very, shallow, and involves endless clicking and micromanagement.  There are few, if any, strategic or consequential decisions.  Building a sprawling city tends to involve less urban planning and more just, flattening land.  In the end I don't feel the same kind of joy that I used to feel designing a sprawling, living society.  The god "powers" are also fairly lacking.  If you want a fairly short but extremely good looking and marvelous taste of what a great god game can look like, try Black and White 2 instead.

content:

Early Access Review
								game is still early access as of time of writing, but as far as I can tell the Devs don't care what their customers have to say anyway, so I wouldn't hold my breath for improvements.all I get from this game is a lot of "you're gonna have a lot of fun ... someday ... if you play exactly as well tell you to, doing nothing fun along the way." and I don't think it's true at all. I don't think I'm ever going to have any fun with this game if every time there's a chance for something fun they go "no, no, we're not doing that- go do this. then do 10 other things in exactly this order because that is the only way to play. also it's going to take a few days of waiting around before you can do those things. grab a book."of course you could use the gem system to speed things up, but I, just like everyone else as far as I can tell, don't want to. the gem system doesn't fit in this game at all and as much as they tell me not to "be afraid" of  it (I'm more annoyed than afraid, but whatever helps you sleep at night I guess), I am thouroughly disinterested in using it. again, it's optional, but only if you're okay with not actually playing the game for more than a few seconds at a time between sessions of waiting.the whole game feels like a tutorial that can't be skipped and I'm left sitting there wondering if I'll ever get around to actually playing a game at some point in the Godus experience instead of just going through the motions (spoiler: I wont!).... then I get frustrated and go play a real, playable, fun game, that lets me play pretty much however I like. lately Prison Architect, Banished or Don't Starve.to close: obvious mobile game is obvious, and absolutely no fun at all. buy something that's actually worth the money.

Early Access Review
								Godus is obviously designed as a "free to play" tablet game. The gameplay is about 1/10th clumsy clicking-and-dragging and 9/10ths waiting for things to pop up that you can click on. The only way to advance the game is performing a few actions, then waiting. Waiting and waiting.  You will need to leave the game running in the background on your PC for hours in order to get 5 minutes of advancement.It's meant to frustrate you into purchasing the stickers and gems that will eliminate the waiting, but the PC version doesn't have these microtransactions.  Instead, it replaces them with hours and hours of pointless waiting.According to the developers the game is "51%" done at this point, but unless they're going to completely redesign it, it is  a complete waste of money.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								I backed this on kickstarter thinking that it would be a PC game with a mobile port, but it turns out it was the other way around. Every system in this game requires waiting for excruciatingly long periods of time. On the iPad, a game that you play for five minutes every hour makes sense, but if you make a PC game that basically requires that you stop playing to progress, then you have failed to make a good game.Some of the more irritating aspects for the controls etc. will, I'm sure, be cleared up in updates, but the fundamental problem with Godus is that all the interesting parts of it are gated behind a long waiting period. Want to sculpt the world? Wait for your belief to accumulate.Want to expand your region? Wait for several hours for the beacon to be activated.Want to build a new structure? Wait 30 minutes for your wheat to grow so you can make a builder.This is a bad PC game, pure and simple. The "fixes" that have been put in to replace the micro-transactions in the iPad version actually slow your game down. The mouse controls are sluggish and unresponsive. You will find that 30% of your population has left because you had the audacity to go to bed one night rather than sit at your PC all night.Everything that is wrong with Godus is linked to the fact that it has been built for playing on an iPad. The only way that Godus can become a good PC game is if they develop the PC version independently of the iPad version. I am sorry I kickstarted this.DO NOT BUY

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								I can't suggest this game. I have been following this game from pretty much the start and no matter what form it takes or no matter how many changes, it just isn't a good game, not at all.The game concepts seem intresting on the surface however they are poorley executed, often you can be left wondering if the developers think about a concept before putting it in, and if they even know what game they are trying to make.One example would be belief, which is your Mana or power to cast God Spells and other goodies. Houses produce is but it runs out far, far too quickly because every action, big or small, consumes it and once gone the only way to get it back is by going on some aannoying voyage which is some kind of mini-game that I HATE. They are annoying, pointless, time consuming. Or wait around twenty mins for your belief to respawn at the houses. Oh and construction takes 15 mins to build a single house in some cases, longer for becons and temples. But wait, there is a way to speed this up! You can click and hold on some of your builders to send them to construction site, oh wait this too consumes HUGE ammount of your power!! All this hampers the ability to create the world you want, how can you without enough prayer power to actually do anything?How can you build a cilivization when it takes so long to build anything?Why, if I am trying to progress this civilization through the ages am I going on pointless voyage mini-games that take me away from the civilization? Is this a long real time game like The Lost Tribes games?Or is it meant to be fast, and exciting?It seems like this game is suffering from an identity crisis one that cannot be resolved no matter how many times you press the restart button. I wanted to like this game and God (excuse the pun) knows I tried. But I am afraid that unless this game seriously starts to pull its act together intrest which is already pretty low will ne non-existent and when the game is finished, when this finished product if polished and shined, there wont be anyone intrested in playing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a review based off a conversation I had with friends, trying to explain my frustration with the game.  I played Godus again.  Nearly 3 hours of it.  The game is terrible.  All they needed to do was remake Populus with some cleaner graphics.  Instead they went a different route.  It's still not commercial yet, but I don't see how they will fix it.  Remember them saying they wanted to make it for PC and mobile?  They've added a pay-to-win system.  You can go buy jewels or diamonds or some bull like that, and trade them in for belief and stickers.  You can't do anything without belief.  You need stickers to upgrade your powers.".... so its just like a God version of every other ♥♥♥♥♥ game"Exactly.  But it's ok (I said sarcastically).  Because on the PC version you aren't allowed to buy diamonds.  Instead you get some while you explore or you can sacrifice a villager to get a diamond.  Of course, you need at least 100 belief to sacrifice a villager...  and it cost 5 diamonds to buy 1000 belief...  So you need belief, so you can sacrifice a villager to get diamonds, so you can buy belief, so you can sacrifice a villager, so you can buy belief...  It's an overwhelmingly broken system.  I mean, at least on mobile I can purchase diamonds and play the game (Please note, this is not a suggestion to allow diamonds on PC, I just want to play the game at a reasonable speed).  I haven't even gotten to the gameplay.  So besides the fact you will literally never have enough belief, stickers, or diamonds...  There's another group of people (the Entarie, or something like that) who are just too happy.  You need to convert them or destroy all of them.  I've turned their entire city into a swamp, I've nailed it with meteors, I've crushed them using "The Finger of God."  and they are having the time of their lives.  It seems to be some stupid system where it takes the average happiness of all your people vs the average happiness of all of theirs, but there is no way to make them unhappy.  So every hour or so 1/4 of your population leaves and swims to their side of the map.  Then you repopulate your houses, throw some meteors, and try to make a settlement before the next hour rolls by and you lose another 1/4 of your population.It's insane.  I had them down to 4 people and they were happier than my 300-ish villagers.I'm going to uninstall it and wait until the next big update comes out.  V2.2 is not good.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Edit; Well i thought I'd check in with Godus again. Its been quietly updating (rarely) as I left it installed.I'll put it this way. FROM DUST, has more strategy than this. FROM DUST has better tribal management than this. FROM DUST has better sculpting/world physics than this. FROM. DUST. That should say everything -.-Ignore my last line saying buy it on offer. Don't buy it at all, especially as two of the Godus devs have jumped ship already and its still not complete.I'll keep it short and simple because atm Godus is still early access and the review will be due to change on release.Very little has changed in regards to User Feedback on Godus. A few tweaks have been made to the basics of the game, but it is still very much an iOS ported game.Gameplay is too.. erratic. I wouldn't say it is slow, the pacing is nice. It is just that you can do things a lot quicker than the timers complete.For example, you set a few building plots going. 15-30minute timers each. So you stay in game thinking you'll find enough to do. 5 minutes later you are out of belief. When you unlock Voyages this extends the time you can spend active while waiting for timers, doing what are effectively "sticker missions" with a few gems thrown in as a reward. But even the voyages don't fill in the time nicely and once you've used up all your available voyages that is basically the game done with for the entire day.Sure you could quit the game and return in an hour, collect the belief accrued, tweak some more terrain, but the core actual gameplay is done with until the voyage timers complete. The mechnics are very skewed to trying to get players to become impatient and abuse the Gem Store by sacrificing villagers and buying belief packs to continue actively playing.Which is what this WHOLE reviews boil down to.Godus is 25% Active gameplay and 75% Passive gameplay (read, waiting around.)Godus dictates -when- you can play it, not the other way around. Which doesn't fit well as a casual game (You want to be able to pick up and play when you can), it doesn't fit well as a pure PC game (PC gamers generally like to remain active, passive waiting for the majority of the game implies your time can be better spent doing something else.)Sure you can multi-task have Godus running in the background, but then you don't want to play any other game because Godus wants your attention every half hour and theres only so much general browsing you can do during those timers.Avoid Godus in its current state, if they refine the timing of the game and make it significantly more active/interesting during the passive down time, then it may be worth a look.Even on release I would be inclined to say avoid it at full price. If you see it on a steam sale at 75%-80% off go for it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								Conceptually the game is a very interesting idea. It just moves way too slowly in my opinion such that I quickly lose interest. You basically have to wait 20 minutes for faith to regenerate every time you want to do something, and even then it's really limited. Very little about the game revolves around anything 'God-like' other than a very small number of powers. It just feels kind of one-dimensional. Especially with the change that sculpting the land is now a more minor component. There just isn't enough content to keep you engaged.Plus, I find the gathering of stickers a huge pain. You spend all this time working towards these achievement cards, only to realise that you need all these 'stickers' to unlock them. The stickers are a pain to collect. There simply are not enough chests.Also, every time I close the game, it continues, which is fine. However, the Astari always accumulate way too much happiness (despite the fact that I placed swamps outside their shrine, and when live in-game they tend to die in it and become unhappy each time a festival happens) and steal all of my followers - wasting all of that time you spent. So the game punishes you for not playing, which just makes you want to play even less. Plus, even if you do gain Astari followers they are completely useless - so what's even the point?There's a lot of potential here for a really great game. However, the flaws are really numerous at this point.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 22, 2013
Early Access Review
								Previously I'd given this game a thumbs up. A few months ago it was pretty fun. You terraformed terrain, expanded your civilization, and amassed belief from your minions to do cool things. But it's become apparent recently that 22cans is not designing a PC game. They're designing a mobile game, and releasing it on PC so they can charge people up front to fund the mobile version.Have you played one of those mobile games where you start out building things and everything is fun, and then by the second day everything takes 4 hours to complete and you can pay to speed it up? And then by the third day everything takes a week to complete? Yeah, that's what Godus is now. You can get "gems" which are a special currency that allows you to, you guessed it, speed things up.The progression system is absurd now. You progress by unlocking cards. And then buying the cards. That's right after you unlock the card you have the privilege of buying it. With stickers. That you receive when you A. buy them with gems, B. get lucky opening chests or C. play the tedious voyage minigame (more below).You know that game you were playing, called Godus? I don't think you really wanted to play that game. I mean, you said you did, but I decided you were going to play lemmings. I mean, go off and play this minigame called "Voyages", which is essentially lemmings. If you win you get stickers! If you lose then your lemmings die and you have to wait a few hours to try again. Or you can just buy the stickers with gems. When you really just wanted to play Godus.In a previous alpha there was a pseudo-PvP feature where you'd build a small civilization head-to-head against an opponent and then get some goodies when you finished it. That was great! It was a microcosm of Godus in a self-contained bubble. But now that's gone and replaced by lemmings. Honestly, if I wanted that I'd just go play lemmings.So, Godus has jumped the shark. I'm pretty sure we all should have seen it coming, since Peter Molyneux has done this a dozen times before. But it's pretty disappointing since Godus USED TO BE FUN. And now has been ruined. Probably forever.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a review based off a conversation I had with friends, trying to explain my frustration with the game.  I played Godus again.  Nearly 3 hours of it.  The game is terrible.  All they needed to do was remake Populus with some cleaner graphics.  Instead they went a different route.  It's still not commercial yet, but I don't see how they will fix it.  Remember them saying they wanted to make it for PC and mobile?  They've added a pay-to-win system.  You can go buy jewels or diamonds or some bull like that, and trade them in for belief and stickers.  You can't do anything without belief.  You need stickers to upgrade your powers.".... so its just like a God version of every other ♥♥♥♥♥ game"Exactly.  But it's ok (I said sarcastically).  Because on the PC version you aren't allowed to buy diamonds.  Instead you get some while you explore or you can sacrifice a villager to get a diamond.  Of course, you need at least 100 belief to sacrifice a villager...  and it cost 5 diamonds to buy 1000 belief...  So you need belief, so you can sacrifice a villager to get diamonds, so you can buy belief, so you can sacrifice a villager, so you can buy belief...  It's an overwhelmingly broken system.  I mean, at least on mobile I can purchase diamonds and play the game (Please note, this is not a suggestion to allow diamonds on PC, I just want to play the game at a reasonable speed).  I haven't even gotten to the gameplay.  So besides the fact you will literally never have enough belief, stickers, or diamonds...  There's another group of people (the Entarie, or something like that) who are just too happy.  You need to convert them or destroy all of them.  I've turned their entire city into a swamp, I've nailed it with meteors, I've crushed them using "The Finger of God."  and they are having the time of their lives.  It seems to be some stupid system where it takes the average happiness of all your people vs the average happiness of all of theirs, but there is no way to make them unhappy.  So every hour or so 1/4 of your population leaves and swims to their side of the map.  Then you repopulate your houses, throw some meteors, and try to make a settlement before the next hour rolls by and you lose another 1/4 of your population.It's insane.  I had them down to 4 people and they were happier than my 300-ish villagers.I'm going to uninstall it and wait until the next big update comes out.  V2.2 is not good.

content:

Early Access Review
								Godus is obviously designed as a "free to play" tablet game. The gameplay is about 1/10th clumsy clicking-and-dragging and 9/10ths waiting for things to pop up that you can click on. The only way to advance the game is performing a few actions, then waiting. Waiting and waiting.  You will need to leave the game running in the background on your PC for hours in order to get 5 minutes of advancement.It's meant to frustrate you into purchasing the stickers and gems that will eliminate the waiting, but the PC version doesn't have these microtransactions.  Instead, it replaces them with hours and hours of pointless waiting.According to the developers the game is "51%" done at this point, but unless they're going to completely redesign it, it is  a complete waste of money.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Ok I will start by saying this. I can tell the developers did try with this game, though not hard enough. I bought this game for $4.99 during a sale and honestly that is as high as you should want to pay for this game(in its current state.) It trys a bit too hard to be like all the other civilization games out there and kinda makes you have to wait for EVERYTHING.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Pros: The game seems like a nice way to spend some free time, getting your followers the biggest and best villages possible, and can easily make cool looking areas.  It has possibilities as to where the over all gameplay can go. The story is a fun read if you can get all the story chests.And over all the ability to make the world to your liking is a cool aspect.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Cons: The game is a slow climb and will eventually start getting a bit boring after sitting there for hours to get things done, and to top it off the bugs kinda kill the fun you "could" have.Its crashes ALL the time(I understand its an early access game) but when it happens every 20-30 minutes and makes your collecting harder to do its time to fix something.The gameplay is TOO repetitive. You can't get all of the story chests if you end up getting the skill that allows for 2 stickers in 1 chest.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~So my final thoughts on this on this game is this. If you want to buy this game then WAIT TILL ITS DONE. The early access version of this is far too bugged and needs much more work. If you do buy this as early access then at least make sure to heed the warnings.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								Buying this game three years ago I was very hopeful to see a new take on the classic game POPULOUS, a interesting game whereby the players are able to influence their followers to beat the opposing team via terrain manipulation and other powers. I was truly excited to see the modern version of this game as I had, at the time, seen games where RTS games featured planetary conquest. After seeing this I was very excited to see what GODUS would feature and the idea of an MMO.At first I thought the game was fun in the first few sessions but as time went on it was pretty obvious in about 3 hours of gameplay I found that the gameplay was rapidly degenerating into busy work and boredom. I gave the game a few more tries and then set it aside to wait for the game to be worked on. I thought that the art work and the promises assuring, along with Molyneux being in charge it was bound to get better. Oh was I wrong.Well three years later, two major patches later,  and I can tell that nothing substantial has been added. The war mechanic was fun for about an hour and then becomes really dull. It just made the game all the more disappointing as it just reinforced the simplistic garbage that is made for phones.I also read on the game's RECENT NEWS tab that there is no release date and that it isn't clear who is still working on this project anymore as the lead developer decided to leave. The fact that the game isn't finished four years later is just unacceptable. I certainly hope the developers will finish this game in whatever state it is and move on to something else to which I wish the best of luck after all this Godus debacle.

content:

Early Access Review
								I have played a good chunk of hours with Godus. At first, it is highly addictive. You get to discover new areas, sculpt land to live on and watch your cities grow, but thats about all you can do. The first 10 hours is just grinding and following along with the guided story after that more grinding to get to that 'just out of reach' next tech level to advance the story only to find out you need three or four more 'level-ups' before any progress can be made. I bought this game when it was first released hoping for a decent population control sim with RTS subtleties. But thats about it, horrible AI and an unrewarding leveling system that stresses grinding and saving is not fun.

								Godus v2.0 still sucks. Its supposed to feel "delicious" now but I disagree. They definitely improved it thats for sure but its still not worth 20$. You don't have to click on every house for belief now but instead drag your mouse over all of them collecting the belief. This is better than before but if it auto-collected for you that would make it a LOT better. Then I'm not really sure who they hired but they have quite a few spelling mistakes in this game. I excuse civilisation because that is real spelling of the word but if you look on your adobe's they say they PREY to you.My followers are preying to me? I am(as dictionary.com says) an animal hunted or seized for food, especially by a carnivorous animal? If so call the police because we have a cannibalistic carnivorous animal who wants us to buy his game. The game is only worth about $5.00 on a good day. You might have more fun with a mobile game though.Edit: It's close to a YEAR later and hardly any significant progress has ben made. In fact the team has almost fallen apart by this point. A reminder why to not EVER buy early access games unless you find them enjoyable already.Edit: Its close to TWO YEARS later. Hardly any progress has been yet made. They have now scrapped Godus and are working on "Godus Wars".Edit: It's THREE YEARS later and the game is still garbage and now has nobody working on it. Godus Wars was a failed attempt to sweep the bad reviews of this game away.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								I bought this game shortly after it was announced on Steam. It has gone through many stages since then. Early on, it had alot of potential. Each major development reduced that potential however.First, development focussed on "sculpting". This was altering the terrain to make it pretty. Build mountains / valleys. Unfortunately, there was no benefit to this. The only time scultping was beneficial was to make "parking lots" so people could build houses. Trees, rocks, hills, rivers, lakes, and valleys did nothing but reduce how many houses would be built; obsticles to be removed. The game rewarded the player for making the world mundane.Second, development wanted to add in progression. It was decided to implement this by having players collect stickers from chests scattered around the world. To collect stickers, one had to find a chest that was either buried, on a hill, or hidden in trees or rocks. More forests were cleared, hills were flattened, and buried treasure dug up and the holes again filled in. Thousands of clicks for the simple task of a never-ending fetch-quest. Mandatory to progress.Third, development pushed toward collecting more IRL money. "Gems" were added and could be purchased to speed the now reduced belief generation, produce random stickers, or make "sculpting" more efficient for a short time. Spend real money to make mundane gameplay faster, not more interesting. The games slipped into the realm of "Freemium"; but you had to buy it first.Forth, "cities" were added. These were "miracles" that clumped existing houses together. Some cities produced "resources". The resources could not be spent and were not produced, they simply existed once built. Instead, they worked like level requirements or keys to unlock more levels of progression. IE "To advance, you need 4 farms".Currently, game development is all but abandonded. I expect this to end similar to StarForged. The heads at the dev studio will declare the game finished and leave the 1/2 finished game.To those looking for a good God Game, I would suggest Black & White or Black & White 2. Not this "Freemium" excuse for a game.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								I bought this game shortly after it was announced on Steam. It has gone through many stages since then. Early on, it had alot of potential. Each major development reduced that potential however.First, development focussed on "sculpting". This was altering the terrain to make it pretty. Build mountains / valleys. Unfortunately, there was no benefit to this. The only time scultping was beneficial was to make "parking lots" so people could build houses. Trees, rocks, hills, rivers, lakes, and valleys did nothing but reduce how many houses would be built; obsticles to be removed. The game rewarded the player for making the world mundane.Second, development wanted to add in progression. It was decided to implement this by having players collect stickers from chests scattered around the world. To collect stickers, one had to find a chest that was either buried, on a hill, or hidden in trees or rocks. More forests were cleared, hills were flattened, and buried treasure dug up and the holes again filled in. Thousands of clicks for the simple task of a never-ending fetch-quest. Mandatory to progress.Third, development pushed toward collecting more IRL money. "Gems" were added and could be purchased to speed the now reduced belief generation, produce random stickers, or make "sculpting" more efficient for a short time. Spend real money to make mundane gameplay faster, not more interesting. The games slipped into the realm of "Freemium"; but you had to buy it first.Forth, "cities" were added. These were "miracles" that clumped existing houses together. Some cities produced "resources". The resources could not be spent and were not produced, they simply existed once built. Instead, they worked like level requirements or keys to unlock more levels of progression. IE "To advance, you need 4 farms".Currently, game development is all but abandonded. I expect this to end similar to StarForged. The heads at the dev studio will declare the game finished and leave the 1/2 finished game.To those looking for a good God Game, I would suggest Black & White or Black & White 2. Not this "Freemium" excuse for a game.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
Early Access Review
NOTE: As this game develops, I will try to revise this review from time to time. Much has changed, but some things are kind of still abysmally (and frustratingly) the same. I actually have hardly played it since the Summer 2014, due to slow development and frustrating game play, so keep that in mind when reading this review; I might be a bit emotionally biased.ReviewI currently cannot recommend this game to the casual player, or... really, any player. Not in it's current state. If you are not prepared to play an unfinished game, in any phase of development, and all that comes with participating in Beta testing, this is not the game for you. If you don't want to give feedback or suggestions about the development of the game, this isn't for you. If you want a finished product, with few bugs, and a well tested gameplay, this is absolutely not for you. If you want a game that reignites the nostalgia of the classic "god games" of a bygone era, then I am very sorry to inform you: This is NOT the game you're looking for. At least, not right now. Wait a bit longer, at least until the official final release - if that ever happens - and then come back and see how it's going. {I'll be repeating this mantra throughout my review}IMPORTANT NEWS: December 2014: The head of development for 22Cans (Peter Molyneux) has recently expressed disappointment in this unfinished game - essentially blaming everything from Crowdfunding, Steam Early Access, and the Player Community, instead of himself - and has astoundingly announced that the company will begin work on a new game, and basically relegating this unfinished game to the sidelines. It will, for now, be manned with a skeleton crew (of skilled designers and programmers) to moderate and develop it further; they're still working out the details, and it's all just barely in the works, but that's the latest news.The {amazing} community managers, whom were very adept at their jobs, were doing a phenomenal job in the last few months, really stepping up to the task of vastly improving communication between the company and community involvement, which was bringing some much needed life back into it. So the shocking and dubious news that things were about to change, and fast, was a bit of a surprise (even to the CM's) and that caused even more strife and turmoil amongst the already near mutinous community. As such, as it seems to go with 22Cans, the above announcement has had an apparent rippling effect; both community managers have announced they will be moving on to new positions, and a couple of the Dev team as well have also bowed out. That is very sad news, and doesn't bode well for things to come.The only shining light is the small crew that may be taking the charge going forward. It appears (from discussions) they have some realistic aspirations, seem reasonably levelheaded, and  so maybe there's hope yet. Where have they been during all this craziness? Well, all that aside, time will tell where this crazy train will take things. The small crew, mentioned above, that may actually give some solid efforts to bring this thing back on course. Here's to hoping - though I'm not holding my breath just yet. Honestly, who knows what this game is or will be? It's still definitely a mobile-like game, and is terribly slanted towards a very "F2P" style game - despite being sold and hyped as a crossover game - and has yet to be fully realized on the PC. It'll take a big shift in design to get it aligned with a more typical desktop platform game, and frankly this may never happen.For now, I would still highly suggest a "Wait and See" approach to this game. Instead, go check out something more 'feature complete' and come back perhaps later next year to see how it's going.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ORIGINAL REVIEW “GODUS is a great idea made in a culture of openness and co-operation."Sadly, this has not been the case. The community has not been as big a part of the project as promised, and have all but been shut out by the developer. The game itself - which has limited playability in it's unfinished state - has not had an update since October 2013, not even a single bug fix.The screenshots are so beautiful, but don't let that fool you. One only has to sit down and play it to experience in person just how mind-numbingly incomplete, and frustrating, it actually is. While I enjoyed the initial gameplay, it quickly turns into a slow paced click-fest that results in severe carpel-tunnel strain and finger stiffness - and that's only after the first hour.  Granted it's still in the "Beta" phase, with much still in development, it feels more like an Alpha release; still needs lots of testing and additional content. It has severely broken AI pathing, incomplete replaybility, and lacks the multiplayer capability that's promised, among other issues. This is supposedly all being fixed, but we have no idea since the devs have kept pretty closed on the details. I liked the aesthetics, the look and feel of the game-world graphics, but that is just one of the few things good about this game. There is so much potential in the idea of the game that it feels unrealized; like they just decided not to follow through with things they planned, or things suggested through the feedback support throughout alpha testing and early access. The gameplay also makes the player question their role as “God” since it seems you do everything for the “populous” except build houses; very little of the actions feel “Godlike” and feel more like micro-managing a landscaping game combined with a baby-sitting simulator. Limited gameplay, poor mechanics, and questionable player actions makes this a tough game to love – and yet it somehow still manages to make you want to love it. I'm very conflicted.Very little info about the progress has been shared with the Backers or Early Access players (read: essentially none) despite the above quote and premise of what the Kickstarter campaign promised, or what most "Early Access" Betas are about; constant development, testing, and community interaction. Supposedly they are working on a major re-design of the fundamental game play, but extremely little has been shared. Also, the Devs supposedly know of the mounting criticism, hostility, and over-all dissatisfaction with the entire project process, but have done very little to alleviate it or address it. We're not certain how much they're allowed to share - controlled by the powers in charge, potentially (likely) through job contracts and NDA agreements - which seems a bit oddly strict for a crowdfunded early-access game. The lack of meaningful communication from the devs themselves is understandable, if the former is true, but the marketing, management and executive PR folks are doing a poor job of informing the early-beta community; instead they avoid talking directly to us, and go on PR stunts to drum up interest in a failing enterprise. At this time in the development, I cannot say I can recommend this game as it currently stands. I DO NOT recommend this Early Access game at this time for the casual player. Time will tell if my mind will be changed by the updates. If the last four months of untested redesign is a waste, or if it will be a game-changer for the better, will be seen.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------TL:DR; NOPE

content:
Posted: November 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have played this game for several hours and had a lot fun doing so.But in the mean time the game is better suited to give to a friend you never want to see again.Pros:- Nice design- Gameplay although slow has its appealCons:- Very few things to do after the initial setup- Only 1 voyage although it says that it will be updated (I am already waiting for several months)- Every time an abode catches fire it can never be extinguised and it will ignite other abodes destroying everything in the proces. - Even if all houses are destroyed the fire still remains "underground" and will ignite other abodes placed on those spots. This meant that after several hours of gameplay you not only lose your civilization you had the patience to build but you cannot restart it using the resource you have collected.- A lot of other bugs in general, non as gamebreaking as the previous ones mentioned but there are still some ctrl + alt +del problems.It is a great game and I have had my fair share of fun. Before the previously mentioned bug appeared I would not recommend this game to any one in its current state (beta v. 2.4). If the bugs are fixed and more gameplay is created it might be worth the 19.99 euro. But currently I would not even accept it as a free gift.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have played a good chunk of hours with Godus. At first, it is highly addictive. You get to discover new areas, sculpt land to live on and watch your cities grow, but thats about all you can do. The first 10 hours is just grinding and following along with the guided story after that more grinding to get to that 'just out of reach' next tech level to advance the story only to find out you need three or four more 'level-ups' before any progress can be made. I bought this game when it was first released hoping for a decent population control sim with RTS subtleties. But thats about it, horrible AI and an unrewarding leveling system that stresses grinding and saving is not fun.
