content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
Early Access Review
NOTE: As this game develops, I will try to revise this review from time to time. Much has changed, but some things are kind of still abysmally (and frustratingly) the same. I actually have hardly played it since the Summer 2014, due to slow development and frustrating game play, so keep that in mind when reading this review; I might be a bit emotionally biased.ReviewI currently cannot recommend this game to the casual player, or... really, any player. Not in it's current state. If you are not prepared to play an unfinished game, in any phase of development, and all that comes with participating in Beta testing, this is not the game for you. If you don't want to give feedback or suggestions about the development of the game, this isn't for you. If you want a finished product, with few bugs, and a well tested gameplay, this is absolutely not for you. If you want a game that reignites the nostalgia of the classic "god games" of a bygone era, then I am very sorry to inform you: This is NOT the game you're looking for. At least, not right now. Wait a bit longer, at least until the official final release - if that ever happens - and then come back and see how it's going. {I'll be repeating this mantra throughout my review}IMPORTANT NEWS: December 2014: The head of development for 22Cans (Peter Molyneux) has recently expressed disappointment in this unfinished game - essentially blaming everything from Crowdfunding, Steam Early Access, and the Player Community, instead of himself - and has astoundingly announced that the company will begin work on a new game, and basically relegating this unfinished game to the sidelines. It will, for now, be manned with a skeleton crew (of skilled designers and programmers) to moderate and develop it further; they're still working out the details, and it's all just barely in the works, but that's the latest news.The {amazing} community managers, whom were very adept at their jobs, were doing a phenomenal job in the last few months, really stepping up to the task of vastly improving communication between the company and community involvement, which was bringing some much needed life back into it. So the shocking and dubious news that things were about to change, and fast, was a bit of a surprise (even to the CM's) and that caused even more strife and turmoil amongst the already near mutinous community. As such, as it seems to go with 22Cans, the above announcement has had an apparent rippling effect; both community managers have announced they will be moving on to new positions, and a couple of the Dev team as well have also bowed out. That is very sad news, and doesn't bode well for things to come.The only shining light is the small crew that may be taking the charge going forward. It appears (from discussions) they have some realistic aspirations, seem reasonably levelheaded, and  so maybe there's hope yet. Where have they been during all this craziness? Well, all that aside, time will tell where this crazy train will take things. The small crew, mentioned above, that may actually give some solid efforts to bring this thing back on course. Here's to hoping - though I'm not holding my breath just yet. Honestly, who knows what this game is or will be? It's still definitely a mobile-like game, and is terribly slanted towards a very "F2P" style game - despite being sold and hyped as a crossover game - and has yet to be fully realized on the PC. It'll take a big shift in design to get it aligned with a more typical desktop platform game, and frankly this may never happen.For now, I would still highly suggest a "Wait and See" approach to this game. Instead, go check out something more 'feature complete' and come back perhaps later next year to see how it's going.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ORIGINAL REVIEW “GODUS is a great idea made in a culture of openness and co-operation."Sadly, this has not been the case. The community has not been as big a part of the project as promised, and have all but been shut out by the developer. The game itself - which has limited playability in it's unfinished state - has not had an update since October 2013, not even a single bug fix.The screenshots are so beautiful, but don't let that fool you. One only has to sit down and play it to experience in person just how mind-numbingly incomplete, and frustrating, it actually is. While I enjoyed the initial gameplay, it quickly turns into a slow paced click-fest that results in severe carpel-tunnel strain and finger stiffness - and that's only after the first hour.  Granted it's still in the "Beta" phase, with much still in development, it feels more like an Alpha release; still needs lots of testing and additional content. It has severely broken AI pathing, incomplete replaybility, and lacks the multiplayer capability that's promised, among other issues. This is supposedly all being fixed, but we have no idea since the devs have kept pretty closed on the details. I liked the aesthetics, the look and feel of the game-world graphics, but that is just one of the few things good about this game. There is so much potential in the idea of the game that it feels unrealized; like they just decided not to follow through with things they planned, or things suggested through the feedback support throughout alpha testing and early access. The gameplay also makes the player question their role as “God” since it seems you do everything for the “populous” except build houses; very little of the actions feel “Godlike” and feel more like micro-managing a landscaping game combined with a baby-sitting simulator. Limited gameplay, poor mechanics, and questionable player actions makes this a tough game to love – and yet it somehow still manages to make you want to love it. I'm very conflicted.Very little info about the progress has been shared with the Backers or Early Access players (read: essentially none) despite the above quote and premise of what the Kickstarter campaign promised, or what most "Early Access" Betas are about; constant development, testing, and community interaction. Supposedly they are working on a major re-design of the fundamental game play, but extremely little has been shared. Also, the Devs supposedly know of the mounting criticism, hostility, and over-all dissatisfaction with the entire project process, but have done very little to alleviate it or address it. We're not certain how much they're allowed to share - controlled by the powers in charge, potentially (likely) through job contracts and NDA agreements - which seems a bit oddly strict for a crowdfunded early-access game. The lack of meaningful communication from the devs themselves is understandable, if the former is true, but the marketing, management and executive PR folks are doing a poor job of informing the early-beta community; instead they avoid talking directly to us, and go on PR stunts to drum up interest in a failing enterprise. At this time in the development, I cannot say I can recommend this game as it currently stands. I DO NOT recommend this Early Access game at this time for the casual player. Time will tell if my mind will be changed by the updates. If the last four months of untested redesign is a waste, or if it will be a game-changer for the better, will be seen.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------TL:DR; NOPE

content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								I seriously feel bad for my coworker who actually purchased this game (I am on his Friends and Family). I have often facetiously accused Bethesda of not having a QA team in Elder Scrolls games, but this is the real deal when it comes to bug riddled death traps. I will frequently get progression blocked because they ask for me to do something (like farming) before they gave me the technology to do so. Luckily it reassesses my ability to do what it asked for on game startup. Will need to reboot my computer to kill off lingering processes that do not show up on task manager (the game freezes every time I quit through the game menu and after force closing to escape the freeze, the music of the game will play until the machine shuts down, for example). I could probably have programmed a better game in a week with no programming knowledge than they have in the year+ they have been at it (the game was 40% complete when my coworker purchased the game last year and it is now 49.5% done, so they obviously just wanted to pocket the money and run with zero effort put into the game). No self respecting company would let anyone outside of QA see this disaster. If you buy this, I guarantee you will be disappointed.

								    (HUGE RANT ALERT, SKIP THIS [paragraph?] TO GET WHAT YOU WANT TO HEAR)I have had this game from the moment it was put on steam.  Please steam, take this pathetic piece of **** off the market. It is a ♥♥♥♥ing iphone game for PC (20$ when I bought it). Litterally. You have to wait hours for buildings to build, those buildings produce belief which is required to build more buildings. There is no purpose to this game nor is it remotley fun. You hunt the hell out of some chests to build a "better" house, but you can't upgrade your previous 300 houses to the better house. So you end up just covering Saudi Arabia before it became a desert with ugly♥♥♥♥♥tents, then right next to it you have 40 story masions with massive statues celebrating how great a god you are. Very Social Class. Much disapoint. pathetic path finding. Get godus for free on iOS and play the same game. (might be 2.99$ now, I got it free and played the same game.) This game is pathetic, has no purpose. Your godly powers include- shaping the land, shaping the land for another 3 hours, logging in every day in 4 hour intervals to collect belief to shape the land more. Oh and when you don't want to wait hours for your pathetic slobs to build a 400 ft. statue of you, instead buy their second currency to Clash Of Clans rush that B. Its basically a f2p game that your pay to for. It says I have 3.9 hours, in reality I have actually clocked in 17.3 hours. (Steam gets weird with stats on your new computer :/ )    Its an iPhone game on steam. If you want to play it, download it on your phone. Its cheaper, and seems more optimized. It contains all of the same features. I have played 17.3 hours of this game, you could consider me a Gamma Tester, (Pre-Alpha Alpha) It has been the same pathetic trash since it started with no real features added. Just aesthetics and bug fixes.                                                                             GamePlay   Wait hours for your buildings to build, buy the currency with US dollar to rush your little scrubs. Spend 4/5 of the game shaping the land for your people and the other 1/5 shaping more for this game's pathfinding. Experince why clash of clans isn't on steam. Chest hunter simulator, spend more then your willing to constantly shape the land to find chest containing cards that you can buy with US dollars. Then use those cards to unlock another card that unlocks better buildings that you can't use until you shape the land more.                                                                                 The GoodGives you plenty of time to masturbate while your steam friends think that your playing a single player game. Looks nice under steam's uninstalled list. Has steam workshop that completely screws the game into a playable experince.  Cheaper and better on iOS market.                                                                               The BadEverything. The game itself. Pathfinding. No objective in the game. Not fun. Costs money to play. Not unique.  Will never come out of testing stage. Chest hunting. Wait for belief to be produced. Every update start over your entire world. Is an iPhone game for PC.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								I wanted to like Godus. Honestly, I did. In its current state, however, it is extremely repetitive and dull. There is little customization, since not only is terraforming the land a royal pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥ but your communities seems to thrive best on flat as possible land. If you want to progress, your goal is to make things as low and flat as possible, since you want to unearth trinkets to make more (ultimately useless) things, such as bigger houses that don't change gameplay in any way. Also, the only way to DO anything is to click every single house multiple times to get your creation points. Without these points, you can do nothing. There is no point to the clicking and having it autofill would make it go from abysmal to just bad, but nonetheless, let the pointless clicking commence! It is the only way you'll play it for more than an hour, anyhow. Filler at its worst. I know it's just beta right now, but even for an alpha this would be pretty pathetic. Where exactly is the 'game'? Coupled witht he fact that the devs don't seem to be actively letting the public know what's going on or updating this title, it is a very depressing turn of events and my expectations for Godus are hopeful, but realistically as low and flat as the lands that I am required to build ad infinitum.

								"You just expand, unlock and explore. Its pretty hard to recommend this game to anyone"Since my last review, the game finally updated. Now, it works again, so I feel I can review this once more.Firstly, this game is not for everyone. Many state this is a zen like experience, I see it as a demi-phone game. Theres lots of clicking, regardless if they say they improved it. A positive thing is they removed the Gems, which led to a incompleted store to buy gems with real money. Even though, you payed around $20 for the game. The games graphics are simplistic and clean, but doesn't look terrible, and there really isn't any music, just some sound effects.There really isn't much to this game to tell you the truth. I guess the timeline still has stuff I haven't seen but they don't seem to change the gameplay to much anyway, You just expand, unlock and explore. Its pretty hard to recommend this game to anyone, I don't mind this game to much, but I tend to have more free time than the average gamer.Will also note that the game seems to still crash after about an hour of constant gameplay.3/10

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is nothing more than an overhyped mobile clicking app. Theres no real gameplay mechanic other than clicking orbs over houses. If you're looking for a tedious repetitive task that you have to perform for hours on end with little or no tangible results to show for it, I'd thouroughly recommend getting a remedial office job instead, at least that way you wont be out of pocket.I may have been a bit too positive about this game in the review so far...It's probably best to look at it this way; Buying this game would be the equivalent of getting naked and paying £15 to be covered in honey and then have a bee's nest thrown at you all whilst standing on burning coals and being hit in the face with various large peices of furniture, such as, but not limited to, sinks, lamps, chairs, desks, and bedside tables. If you're a masochist and this has sounded just like your cup of tea, you'd still be wrong, for while this is agonisingly dull, it's still just that, dull. It evokes no emotion other than sheer boredom and apathy, so in short, the only way you could enjoy this game is if you either did not have the mental capacity to press more than one button, or you were in a coma...or dead. In fact, I think people with the mental capacity to only press one button, would slip into a coma playing this game, and people in a coma would die.In short, there should be a health warning attached to this game [ Will cause premature death ]

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
Early Access Review
								The idea and concept behind this game are wonderful, but the execution leaves a lot to be desired. Ill admit I havent played this game a tremendous amount. The game starts out a bit slow, which is fine, but must be mentioned as this could turn off some. As you will see others say, this game has mouse clicking that could only be rivaled by minesweeper. The Double click option to add or subtract land an area is novel, but doesn't work all the time ending in a decent amount of wasted faith. Whats faith you may ask, its what you get when you have more people or destroy rocks/trees. You need it to make any moves which is what can slow down the game substantially. Make too many moves and you better get a recliner and go take a bio break because its going to be a bit before you make moves again. I have no problems with a slow paced game, but at times watching a snail race would be more exciting than waiting for your villagers to have faith bubbles show up before you can move again.The multiplayer is a joke and even more minesweeper like. The whole premise is that you need to claim more land (ie have more houses down) to have the higher population count before the time runs out. You are matched up to some other random person and the battle begins. multiplayer is a pointless extra which doesn't add anything to the game imo. A co-op mode would have been a tremendous amount more fun as long as it didnt have to be turn based.I know its still in development, but its updates are soo few and far between its almost a slap in the face to their fans. By comparison, go look how fast Castle Story and Craft the World fix bugs and how often they patch and update their games. Those are phenomenal games still in development by separate companies who both seem to appreciate their fans and genuinely want to give them the best gaming experience possible.So, whats it worth? $20 USD - not a chance. Honestly with the way things are going this game is more of a $5USD as it does provide some entertainment, but it has flaws on almost every edge. I hope the devs eventually step up and improve this game, but as it stands its a sincere flop.

								Game plays more like Curiosity than Black & White, or any other god game for that matter.  Click the ground, keep clicking the ground, then click the ground some more.  As a powerful deity, your abilities are limited to barely more than that of a typical bulldozer and the secret to winning seems to be nothing more than digging up treasure chests and flattening the ground.  Game length is artificially lengthened by timers everywhere.  Follower starts building a house?  Minute and a half before it's finished.  Waiting for a house to spawn a new follower?  Watch the countdown clock.  These aren't even progress meters or anything else that might make sense, they are literal timers ticking away the seconds.  I'm fine and dandy with stuff taking time to complete, but compared to other games with building involved, Godus crawls at a snail's pace.Maybe there will be some actual gameplay in the final release, but for now, skip this and play Black & White if you have a hankering to rule over a society.

								After 80 minutes into the game, I made a little headway in terms of progression, got my guys to a decent population number and made a bit of general progress. content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								Godus is primarily developed as a mobile Pay-to-Win game making use of waiting mechanics and shallow tap and drag based controls. The Steam release for PC/Mac adds no further strategy or interest. Bearing in mind that Godus has been in development for over a year, and that no major features have been added in the last six months, it's hard to justify what 22Cans have been doing, or plan to do in the future with the PC Port.I recommend avoiding this title, at least until it comes out of Early Access or shows some progress towards improving the PC version. At this moment, it's a dull experience, lacking in game play, and there's not much enjoyment to be had.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								I seriously feel bad for my coworker who actually purchased this game (I am on his Friends and Family). I have often facetiously accused Bethesda of not having a QA team in Elder Scrolls games, but this is the real deal when it comes to bug riddled death traps. I will frequently get progression blocked because they ask for me to do something (like farming) before they gave me the technology to do so. Luckily it reassesses my ability to do what it asked for on game startup. Will need to reboot my computer to kill off lingering processes that do not show up on task manager (the game freezes every time I quit through the game menu and after force closing to escape the freeze, the music of the game will play until the machine shuts down, for example). I could probably have programmed a better game in a week with no programming knowledge than they have in the year+ they have been at it (the game was 40% complete when my coworker purchased the game last year and it is now 49.5% done, so they obviously just wanted to pocket the money and run with zero effort put into the game). No self respecting company would let anyone outside of QA see this disaster. If you buy this, I guarantee you will be disappointed.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is nothing more than an overhyped mobile clicking app. Theres no real gameplay mechanic other than clicking orbs over houses. If you're looking for a tedious repetitive task that you have to perform for hours on end with little or no tangible results to show for it, I'd thouroughly recommend getting a remedial office job instead, at least that way you wont be out of pocket.I may have been a bit too positive about this game in the review so far...It's probably best to look at it this way; Buying this game would be the equivalent of getting naked and paying £15 to be covered in honey and then have a bee's nest thrown at you all whilst standing on burning coals and being hit in the face with various large peices of furniture, such as, but not limited to, sinks, lamps, chairs, desks, and bedside tables. If you're a masochist and this has sounded just like your cup of tea, you'd still be wrong, for while this is agonisingly dull, it's still just that, dull. It evokes no emotion other than sheer boredom and apathy, so in short, the only way you could enjoy this game is if you either did not have the mental capacity to press more than one button, or you were in a coma...or dead. In fact, I think people with the mental capacity to only press one button, would slip into a coma playing this game, and people in a coma would die.In short, there should be a health warning attached to this game [ Will cause premature death ]

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
Early Access Review
								The idea and concept behind this game are wonderful, but the execution leaves a lot to be desired. Ill admit I havent played this game a tremendous amount. The game starts out a bit slow, which is fine, but must be mentioned as this could turn off some. As you will see others say, this game has mouse clicking that could only be rivaled by minesweeper. The Double click option to add or subtract land an area is novel, but doesn't work all the time ending in a decent amount of wasted faith. Whats faith you may ask, its what you get when you have more people or destroy rocks/trees. You need it to make any moves which is what can slow down the game substantially. Make too many moves and you better get a recliner and go take a bio break because its going to be a bit before you make moves again. I have no problems with a slow paced game, but at times watching a snail race would be more exciting than waiting for your villagers to have faith bubbles show up before you can move again.The multiplayer is a joke and even more minesweeper like. The whole premise is that you need to claim more land (ie have more houses down) to have the higher population count before the time runs out. You are matched up to some other random person and the battle begins. multiplayer is a pointless extra which doesn't add anything to the game imo. A co-op mode would have been a tremendous amount more fun as long as it didnt have to be turn based.I know its still in development, but its updates are soo few and far between its almost a slap in the face to their fans. By comparison, go look how fast Castle Story and Craft the World fix bugs and how often they patch and update their games. Those are phenomenal games still in development by separate companies who both seem to appreciate their fans and genuinely want to give them the best gaming experience possible.So, whats it worth? $20 USD - not a chance. Honestly with the way things are going this game is more of a $5USD as it does provide some entertainment, but it has flaws on almost every edge. I hope the devs eventually step up and improve this game, but as it stands its a sincere flop.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								Even after that big patch, this game is still a disapointment. Mechanics of the game seem good at first, then become a burden. Prepare your clicks, because you're gonna do a lot of them. The progression system, based mats you find in chests, is flawed. And it brings the dreaded shadow of micro transaction system. Devs are saying there won't be any, but the game is pretty much designed to make it feel like a necessity. What you will find in this game is half waiting, half clicking. Click to get belief (res for doing things in the world), click to send builders, click to sculpt the world. Get yourself some patience, a strong mouse, and dive into the emptiness of this game.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								There have been many complaints regarding the clickity click nature of this game. I used to handle this by using a macro that clicked really fast. This allowed me to sculpt the landscape with relative ease, levelling entire mountains!The update that has been rolled out has made that imposisble, now most interaction requires dragging. Furthermore I have had various freezes (where I could not see anything anymore except ocean) and gotten stuck in tutorials because I did not know what to do or how to do it, without hints on the screen, or because I was whisked away to a 'lost followed' unable to complete the tutorial.Tl;DR wasn't too bad but I could work around it, but now it got worse and I can no longer work around it. As a programmer I am a god, but this game is taking away my ability and will to excercise it within the- apparently now more restiricted- confines Godus.

								This is by far the most boring game in my library. It one of those purchases you regret everytime you see it, and I got it on sale.    This game consists of clicking, clicking, and more clicking.  The resource in this game is belief, which appears in pink bubbles over houses.  You can never get enough belief, in fact you will have to click all the houses every couple minutes to get more.  There is one feature, a town statue, that lets you click one object to collect all the belief in one area, but after about the 4th town you place it becomes near impossible to place anymore as you cannot obtain gems to do so.  Just don't buy this game, it is the most boring, and yet frustrating thing I have ever played.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								I wanted to like Godus. Honestly, I did. In its current state, however, it is extremely repetitive and dull. There is little customization, since not only is terraforming the land a royal pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥ but your communities seems to thrive best on flat as possible land. If you want to progress, your goal is to make things as low and flat as possible, since you want to unearth trinkets to make more (ultimately useless) things, such as bigger houses that don't change gameplay in any way. Also, the only way to DO anything is to click every single house multiple times to get your creation points. Without these points, you can do nothing. There is no point to the clicking and having it autofill would make it go from abysmal to just bad, but nonetheless, let the pointless clicking commence! It is the only way you'll play it for more than an hour, anyhow. Filler at its worst. I know it's just beta right now, but even for an alpha this would be pretty pathetic. Where exactly is the 'game'? Coupled witht he fact that the devs don't seem to be actively letting the public know what's going on or updating this title, it is a very depressing turn of events and my expectations for Godus are hopeful, but realistically as low and flat as the lands that I am required to build ad infinitum.

content:

Early Access Review
								I reviewed this game two updates ago so I felt it was time to re-evaluate and review this game again. In my previous review, I said not to buy this game until it's been fully released. Now, I'm telling you not to buy this game at all. The recent updates have made this version of the game some where hybrid crossbreed with the mobile version. The microtransaction element is there, the long wait times for building projects is there. Between those aspects and the godawful voiceover "tutorial", this game is now nearly unplayable. I have builders building houses and I have to wait EIGHTEEN MINUTES for them to finish. That's absolutely ridiculous. This is a PC game, guys, not a mobile game. If you're going to make two versions then either make them vary by platform or just be honest with us and only release it for mobile. Ambitious game, AWFUL execution.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								"You just expand, unlock and explore. Its pretty hard to recommend this game to anyone"Since my last review, the game finally updated. My last review was fairly aggressive purely because the game was unplayable for me, therefore was absolutely useless while I couldn't play it. Now, it works again, so I feel I can review this once more.Firstly, this game is not for everyone. Many state this is a zen like experience, I see it as a demi-phone game. Theres lots of clicking, regardless if they say they improved it. A positive thing is they removed the Gems, which led to a incompleted store to buy gems with real money. Even though, you payed around $20 for the game. The games graphics are simplistic and clean, but doesn't look terrible, and there really isn't any music, just some sound effects.There really isn't much to this game to tell you the truth. I guess the timeline still has stuff I haven't seen but they don't seem to change the gameplay to much anyway, You just expand, unlock and explore. Its pretty hard to recommend this game to anyone, I don't mind this game to much, but I tend to have more free time than the average gamer.Will also note that the game seems to still crash after about an hour of constant gameplay.3/10

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is nothing more than an overhyped mobile clicking app. Theres no real gameplay mechanic other than clicking orbs over houses. If you're looking for a tedious repetitive task that you have to perform for hours on end with little or no tangible results to show for it, I'd thouroughly recommend getting a remedial office job instead, at least that way you wont be out of pocket.I may have been a bit too positive about this game in the review so far...It's probably best to look at it this way; Buying this game would be the equivalent of getting naked and paying £15 to be covered in honey and then have a bee's nest thrown at you all whilst standing on burning coals and being hit in the face with various large peices of furniture, such as, but not limited to, sinks, lamps, chairs, desks, and bedside tables. If you're a masochist and this has sounded just like your cup of tea, you'd still be wrong, for while this is agonisingly dull, it's still just that, dull. It evokes no emotion other than sheer boredom and apathy, so in short, the only way you could enjoy this game is if you either did not have the mental capacity to press more than one button, or you were in a coma...or dead. In fact, I think people with the mental capacity to only press one button, would slip into a coma playing this game, and people in a coma would die.In short, there should be a health warning attached to this game [ Will cause premature death ]

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
Early Access Review
								The idea and concept behind this game are wonderful, but the execution leaves a lot to be desired. Ill admit I havent played this game a tremendous amount. The game starts out a bit slow, which is fine, but must be mentioned as this could turn off some. As you will see others say, this game has mouse clicking that could only be rivaled by minesweeper. The Double click option to add or subtract land an area is novel, but doesn't work all the time ending in a decent amount of wasted faith. Whats faith you may ask, its what you get when you have more people or destroy rocks/trees. You need it to make any moves which is what can slow down the game substantially. Make too many moves and you better get a recliner and go take a bio break because its going to be a bit before you make moves again. I have no problems with a slow paced game, but at times watching a snail race would be more exciting than waiting for your villagers to have faith bubbles show up before you can move again.The multiplayer is a joke and even more minesweeper like. The whole premise is that you need to claim more land (ie have more houses down) to have the higher population count before the time runs out. You are matched up to some other random person and the battle begins. multiplayer is a pointless extra which doesn't add anything to the game imo. A co-op mode would have been a tremendous amount more fun as long as it didnt have to be turn based.I know its still in development, but its updates are soo few and far between its almost a slap in the face to their fans. By comparison, go look how fast Castle Story and Craft the World fix bugs and how often they patch and update their games. Those are phenomenal games still in development by separate companies who both seem to appreciate their fans and genuinely want to give them the best gaming experience possible.So, whats it worth? $20 USD - not a chance. Honestly with the way things are going this game is more of a $5USD as it does provide some entertainment, but it has flaws on almost every edge. I hope the devs eventually step up and improve this game, but as it stands its a sincere flop.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								Even after that big patch, this game is still a disapointment. Mechanics of the game seem good at first, then become a burden. Prepare your clicks, because you're gonna do a lot of them. The progression system, based mats you find in chests, is flawed. And it brings the dreaded shadow of micro transaction system. Devs are saying there won't be any, but the game is pretty much designed to make it feel like a necessity. What you will find in this game is half waiting, half clicking. Click to get belief (res for doing things in the world), click to send builders, click to sculpt the world. Get yourself some patience, a strong mouse, and dive into the emptiness of this game.

content:

Early Access Review
								There have been many complaints regarding the clickity click nature of this game. I used to handle this by using a macro that clicked really fast. This allowed me to sculpt the landscape with relative ease, levelling entire mountains!The update that has been rolled out has made that imposisble, now most interaction requires dragging. Furthermore I have had various freezes (where I could not see anything anymore except ocean) and gotten stuck in tutorials because I did not know what to do or how to do it, without hints on the screen, or because I was whisked away to a 'lost followed' unable to complete the tutorial.Tl;DR wasn't too bad but I could work around it, but now it got worse and I can no longer work around it. As a programmer I am a god, but this game is taking away my ability and will to excercise it within the- apparently now more restiricted- confines Godus.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
Early Access Review
								Game plays more like Curiosity than Black & White, or any other god game for that matter.  Click the ground, keep clicking the ground, then click the ground some more.  As a powerful deity, your abilities are limited to barely more than that of a typical bulldozer and the secret to winning seems to be nothing more than digging up treasure chests and flattening the ground.  Game length is artificially lengthened by timers everywhere.  Follower starts building a house?  Minute and a half before it's finished.  Waiting for a house to spawn a new follower?  Watch the countdown clock.  These aren't even progress meters or anything else that might make sense, they are literal timers ticking away the seconds.  I'm fine and dandy with stuff taking time to complete, but compared to other games with building involved, Godus crawls at a snail's pace.Maybe there will be some actual gameplay in the final release, but for now, skip this and play Black & White if you have a hankering to rule over a society.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								I seriously feel bad for my coworker who actually purchased this game (I am on his Friends and Family). I have often facetiously accused Bethesda of not having a QA team in Elder Scrolls games, but this is the real deal when it comes to bug riddled death traps. I will frequently get progression blocked because they ask for me to do something (like farming) before they gave me the technology to do so. Luckily it reassesses my ability to do what it asked for on game startup. Will need to reboot my computer to kill off lingering processes that do not show up on task manager (the game freezes every time I quit through the game menu and after force closing to escape the freeze, the music of the game will play until the machine shuts down, for example). I could probably have programmed a better game in a week with no programming knowledge than they have in the year+ they have been at it (the game was 40% complete when my coworker purchased the game last year and it is now 49.5% done, so they obviously just wanted to pocket the money and run with zero effort put into the game). No self respecting company would let anyone outside of QA see this disaster. If you buy this, I guarantee you will be disappointed.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								    (HUGE RANT ALERT, SKIP THIS [paragraph?] TO GET WHAT YOU WANT TO HEAR)I have had this game from the moment it was put on steam.  Please steam, take this pathetic piece of **** off the market. It is a ♥♥♥♥ing iphone game for PC (20$ when I bought it). Litterally. You have to wait hours for buildings to build, those buildings produce belief which is required to build more buildings. There is no purpose to this game nor is it remotley fun. You hunt the hell out of some chests to build a "better" house, but you can't upgrade your previous 300 houses to the better house. So you end up just covering Saudi Arabia before it became a desert with ugly♥♥♥♥♥tents, then right next to it you have 40 story masions with massive statues celebrating how great a god you are. Very Social Class. Much disapoint. pathetic path finding. Get godus for free on iOS and play the same game. (might be 2.99$ now, I got it free and played the same game.) This game is pathetic, has no purpose. Your godly powers include- shaping the land, shaping the land for another 3 hours, logging in every day in 4 hour intervals to collect belief to shape the land more. Oh and when you don't want to wait hours for your pathetic slobs to build a 400 ft. statue of you, instead buy their second currency to Clash Of Clans rush that B. Its basically a f2p game that your pay to for. It says I have 3.9 hours, in reality I have actually clocked in 17.3 hours. (Steam gets weird with stats on your new computer :/ )    Its an iPhone game on steam. If you want to play it, download it on your phone. Its cheaper, and seems more optimized. It contains all of the same features. I have played 17.3 hours of this game, you could consider me a Gamma Tester, (Pre-Alpha Alpha) It has been the same pathetic trash since it started with no real features added. Just aesthetics and bug fixes.                                                                             GamePlay   Wait hours for your buildings to build, buy the currency with US dollar to rush your little scrubs. Spend 4/5 of the game shaping the land for your people and the other 1/5 shaping more for this game's pathfinding. Experince why clash of clans isn't on steam. Chest hunter simulator, spend more then your willing to constantly shape the land to find chest containing cards that you can buy with US dollars. Then use those cards to unlock another card that unlocks better buildings that you can't use until you shape the land more.                                                                                 The GoodGives you plenty of time to masturbate while your steam friends think that your playing a single player game. Looks nice under steam's uninstalled list. Has steam workshop that completely screws the game into a playable experince.  Cheaper and better on iOS market.                                                                               The BadEverything. The game itself. Pathfinding. No objective in the game. Not fun. Costs money to play. Not unique.  Will never come out of testing stage. Chest hunting. Wait for belief to be produced. Every update start over your entire world. Is an iPhone game for PC.

								Honestly I just don't see the point of this game. It's awful at explaining progression and doesn't seem to have any strong overarching theme or plot. At the same time, your accomplishments are nearly impossible to quantify in a satisfactory manner. There doesn't seem to be any challenge except to your patience. Simply put, I heavily regret buying this game.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								I really enjoyed this game at first. It was quirky, relaxing, and basically a satisfying God game for the modern PC era.Then, after one of the beta updates, it tanked.Idk, maybe it was angry that I'm a Mac user and wanted to sing the praises of Windows machines. Then again, maybe it crashes the same on those as well. In any case, when it became apparent that no amount of "hotfixes" and "patches" (however few and far between they were) could salvage the perpetual crashing, I realized that what I was looking at here was ABANDONWARE. If you enjoy the sensation of paying for a fun little game only for it to be ripped out of your hands and your money thrown into a cyberspace void, by all means go for it. Go for Godus Wars, as well. How long before the devs give up on that one?

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Ranting raving review ahead: I'd given this game the benefit of the doubt from day one, thinking that it's still in early access and they're still developing ideas and so on.. But every single update breaks the game more and more. It has become more a mobile idle game that you should not ever turn off for fear of having everything go wrong and being unable to progress any further in the game.  E.G. At the time of writing this every time I open the game up and lose villagers because I closed the game and they got cranky. Which then meant I had hours and hours of wait times pop up and had no villagers to do anything with. I tried Godus, I really tried to stick with you, but every update introduces more mechanics and changes ones that were fantastic for a PC game. Pick a port, PC or mobile and develop it for one, because in trying to develop for both, its broken and will forever be broken. /Rant over.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								An example of bad early access. Other projects are being worked on before this is finished and the team has reduced a lot for this product.It actually wasn't that bad to start with but generally speaking it feels a bit like a chore. I would describe it more as a mobile game where you would maybe play it when you have a few minutes waiting around with not much else to do.Generally speaking you can flattern the land, "inspire" the people to expand, convert another group (which generally means take forever to deal with them or just wipe them out with god powers) and generally some minor things which are more like keeping the game going rather than having nothing to do constantly.It likely could have been decent but most of the promises seem to be broken or flat out lied about. The game fits a mobile area better where you can pull off timers more since their isn't really enough content. It feels like a mobile ported game which honestly is very rare to have done decently.I wouldn't advise anyone to buy this game for the asking price. Maybe if it was on deal for 90% off and you were ok with the idea of it having little life but even then I would question why you would spend so much. Most of my game time was basically behind timers and while I might have had a little fun it will likely never be finished.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Game is terribly un-fun.  I loved populous, Black & White, SIMS, Sim City, etc.  I want to be able to play this game without the interface and the mechanics driving me to stop playing while I wait on timers only to wake up to find that events occurred while I was asleep to make me repeatedly lose followers.  It's an unending grind just to get basic things to function (like building up your followers abodes by flattening land).  It's not the flattening of land that's the grind, it's the waiting to get resources to allow you to sculpt.  You CAN get resources by murdering your followers, but that doesn't make this a god game, it makes this a horrible game.  I want to be a good guy and city-craft and win over my opponents with benevolence.  Not sacrifice my own followers and burn down my enemies.  The essence of the god-game genre should be based on this choice; and there is no choice.  You just wait forever and watch bad things happen to you or turn evil.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Land needs to be flattened in order for your followers to build houses. There is utterly no point in having differing levels of land as it simply limits the number of houses that can be built. So you spend all of your saved belief flattening the land (which is eye-gouging-ly boring) so more houses can be built and you get more belief.....so you can flatten more land and build more houses etc etc...ad-infinitum.Discovering chests is a neat idea but the rewards are mostly things you need to expand the amount of land that's 'yours'...so you can flatten it so more houses can be built...The real problem is you don't actually feel very God-like at all. The ability to move land around feels like an unecessary gimmick rather than a core mechanic. Your followers will all act in the same way regardless of how they are treated. Like faithful puppy dogs they will rebuild a house you've just torn to the ground and carry on as if nothing has happened. Your actions have no consequence, which is a terrible indictment for a game purporting to allow you to be a God.
